message: Today I gave my first speech on the Senate floor.  In this great legislative body, Senators across the political spectrum have a long history of coming together to keep our nation safe, to ensure our children, seniors, and veterans are cared for, and to promote policies that create American jobs. In that tradition, we should use the opportunity of a new year and a new Congress to focus on issues that bring the American people together and make our nation and economy stronger.  Unfortunately, on the first day of this session, the GOP leadership chose not to focus on issues that unite us, but instead launched a process that tramples on the rights of Marylanders and is designed to dismantle the Affordable Care Act without presenting any alternative. This isn’t only irresponsible, it’s downright dangerous for those who would lose their access to health coverage. And it would hurt every taxpayer by adding trillions to the deficit.  So I implore my Senate colleagues to examine their conscience and carefully consider the impact of putting their constituents at risk.  I am honored by the faith Marylanders have placed in me to represent them in this great body. I pledge to them – and to all Americans – that I will strive every day to work for the common good of all people.
The GOP’s plan to destroy ACA patient protections would endanger care for millions of Americans. We're fighting for the health of all.

The human cost of repealing the Affordable Care Act would be so immense, it can be hard to comprehend how it would affect our own families and neighbors. Those on the front lines of care, like Baltimore’s Health Commissioner, Dr. Leana Wen, know better than anyone how much it has improved health in our country.   Before the ACA, one of Dr. Wen’s patients couldn’t afford expensive seizure medication for his young son. The boy suffered a catastrophic seizure and died. Our system failed him, but we passed the ACA to give families the protections and care they need to prevent such tragedies.   There are certainly ways we can improve our health care system – I have put proposals on the table – but let’s not dismantle a system that is saving lives and providing care for those who need it the most.

Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. famously said "the arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends toward justice." Let us each resolve to do our part to bend that arc toward justice. As my friend and great leader, Rep. John Lewis said today in Miami, "when you see something that is not right, not fair, not just, you have a moral obligation to do something, say something and not be quiet."  As we celebrate this day, let us heed those words and fight any efforts to turn back the clock on social justice in America. Let us dedicate ourselves to mobilizing to build an ever more perfect union with liberty and justice for all.

The Attorney General holds a very special position in our democracy, serving as a champion for the people and a defender of those whose only power lies in their rights under the law and in our Constitution. Nominees must be judged based on whether their life's work demonstrates a commitment to meeting the mission of the office they are asked to lead. The Latin motto on the Department of Justice's seal refers to the Attorney General as the one ‘who prosecutes on behalf of justice.’ The Attorney General must be the people’s lawyer and be zealous in the pursuit of justice for all Americans. After reviewing the record of Senator Sessions, I am not convinced that he will be a vigorous defender of the rights of all Americans, especially those who have fallen victim to the powerful or the status quo.   Long before I considered running for elected office myself, I had the honor of working for Senator Mac Mathias of Maryland. In 1986, despite being a member of the Republican Party, Senator Mathias was one of the deciding votes against then U.S. Attorney Sessions' nomination for a federal judgeship.   Since then, Senator Sessions’ statements and actions have done little to reassure Americans. On the contrary, his record of words and deeds—with respect to civil rights, voting rights, women's rights,  LGBT rights, and the rights of individuals with disabilities—reveal that he too often sides with the powerful and the status quo rather than standing up for justice for all. We need an Attorney General who will apply the law to make more real the promise of equal rights and equal justice in America, and the record to date indicates that Senator Sessions fails to meet that important test.   In addition, I am deeply troubled by the positions Senator Sessions has taken on issues related to immigration reform and I am not persuaded that he would be an independent check on an incoming President who has made clear that he is prepared to trample the rights of immigrants and religious minorities.   For all these reasons, while I respect Senator Sessions' record of service to his state in the Senate for 20 years, I do not believe he should serve as our next Attorney General.

Scott Pruitt has spent his career attacking the EPA and its mission to protect our air, our water, and vital ecosystems like our beloved Chesapeake Bay. He has been a puppet for Big Oil and rejects the basic science of climate change. Putting him in charge of the EPA would violate the common wisdom that you don't ask a fox to guard the hen house. I oppose his nomination to lead the EPA.   In addition to being a natural treasure, the Chesapeake Bay is a key lifeline for Maryland's economy – for tourism, the boating industry, and the watermen who harvest the bounty of the Bay. The EPA plays a critical role in protecting the health of the Bay watershed. Yet, as the Attorney General of the landlocked state of Oklahoma, Mr. Pruitt sued the EPA to undermine our Bay cleanup efforts. Fortunately, the courts rejected this interference and our cleanup work continues. But based on his record, we cannot trust Mr. Pruitt be a good federal partner in our mission to protect the Bay.  This is just one piece of Attorney General Pruitt’s long history of opposing efforts to protect our air, our water, and the environment. Former Republican EPA Administrator Christine Todd Whitman summed it up well when she said, ‘I don’t recall ever having seen an appointment of someone who is so disdainful of the agency and the science behind what the agency does.’  As we consider nominations, we must ask this most basic question: will the nominee faithfully carry out the mission of the office to which he or she has been nominated? Based on the record of Scott Pruitt, the answer is no.

The education and success of our children is central to the hopes and dreams of every family in Maryland and across the country, and it is integral to our nation’s future. With that in mind, the Department of Education is charged with one of America’s most critical tasks – providing all children, in every neighborhood, from pre-K to college, with the tools they need to reach their dreams. It is a department that needs strong leadership with a clear vision. And after this week’s confirmation hearing, it is apparent that Betsy DeVos is not the right person for the job.  Mrs. DeVos displayed a concerning lack of knowledge about some of the most important issues in the education community, from how to measure student progress to how to make college more affordable. We must do much more to strengthen our schools, but her belief that we should prioritize school voucher programs and for-profit charter schools above public education is a convenient excuse for not investing adequate resources in our public schools. Her refusal to unequivocally state that she would enforce protections for children with disabilities was appalling. And her cavalier response on the issue of guns in schools deeply disturbed me.    I do not believe that she has the experience necessary to manage such a vital agency or the demonstrated commitment to equal access to a high-quality education for every child. I cannot support Mrs. DeVos’s nomination as Secretary of the Department of Education.

President Trump’s decision to enact an arbitrary hiring freeze on federal agencies is short-sighted and may ultimately cost taxpayers more as that work is shifted to federal contractors. Rather than take the time to understand agency budgets and make informed decisions, the President has decided to forbid agencies from bringing new talent into the civilian workforce. This will jeopardize critical missions like securing our borders, conducting oversight of federal programs, providing Social Security benefits, and monitoring the safety of our food supply. The size of each federal agency’s workforce should rise or fall based on the priority of their missions, not an arbitrary freeze. Unfortunately, this knee-jerk decision involved as much thought as one of the President's many tweets.

When we review each of President Trump’s nominees, we must consider the question of experience. Unlike some of the men and women up for consideration, Steve Mnuchin has experience working with banks. But that experience is some of the most troubling part of his record.  Last week, I had the opportunity to listen to families who had been mistreated by Steve Mnuchin’s bank, OneWest. They each told a different story, but the overall impact was clear – at every turn, OneWest chose to foreclose on homes instead of working with these Americans to keep a roof over their heads. Mr. Mnuchin’s bank was actually nicknamed a ‘foreclosure machine.’   At the height of the housing crisis, my Congressional office was flooded with calls from Marylanders who were in desperate need of help, up against some banks that were only interested in profit, and had nowhere else to turn. We were able to work with many families to help them keep their homes – but that work is not over, and communities in my state and across the country are still recovering. To install someone as the Secretary of the Treasury who engaged in such predatory lending practices and profited off the misery of others is deeply concerning. In recent testimony before a forum of outside witnesses about Mr. Mnuchin’s nomination, an expert witness described OneWest’s abuses as among the worst of the worst.  Mr. Mnuchin’s nomination also represents an astonishing about-face of President Trump’s campaign promise to drain the swamp. Despite campaign-trail promises of openness, Mr. Mnuchin failed to list $100 million in assets in his financial disclosure forms and to disclose his connections to an investment fund in the tax-haven Cayman Islands. And while he claims tax reform should prioritize middle class families, as Secretary of the Treasury he would be charged with implementing a Republican agenda that favors special interests and the ultra-wealthy over everyone and everything else.  The Secretary of the Treasury must do what’s best for American taxpayers, workers, and homeowners. Given his record, I do not believe Mr. Mnuchin meets that standard and I oppose his nomination.

It is outrageous that a 5-year-old boy—an American citizen and Maryland resident—was detained for more than 4 hours this evening at Dulles airport. He was held despite the fact that we gave the authorities advance notice of his arrival earlier today and, when I called later in the evening, they refused to say whether he had been released or was still in custody. Shame on you, Donald Trump. And thank goodness for the federal judge who upheld the rule of law and temporarily blocked the implementation of Trump’s removal order.  We must remain vigilant and fight back.

The announcement that President Trump has added Steve Bannon to the principals committee of the National Security Council and removed the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the Director of National Intelligence is insane. It opens up our country’s top national security decision making body to an individual who the Ku Klux Klan and the American Nazi Party have cheered — and at the same time reduces the role of those charged with America’s defense and intelligence operations.    GOP leaders who care about this country, our democracy, and our role in the world should be as disturbed as the rest of us and need to stand against this. We now have a situation where our Commander-in-Chief appears to be acting more like Vladimir Putin than an American president.

This evening we gathered to unite behind the effort to stop President Trump from weakening our democracy. His un-American ban on refugees and immigrants undermines our security by playing right into the hands of ISIS and diminishes our leadership in the world. We must do everything we can to prevent our country from going down this path.

Today, I voted against the confirmation of Rex Tillerson to serve as Secretary of State.   My father served in the Foreign Service at the Department of State, so I spent some of my early years overseas. I was proud to be part of a family that represented our great Country. I learned firsthand the critical role of our Nation’s diplomats, the risks that they take to serve our Country, and the part that they play in spreading American ideals of freedom and democracy around the world.  The State Department reaches across the world, advancing our interests, shaping our relationships, advocating for human rights, and working to advance peace. But it is a department that has been deeply shaken by President Trump’s dangerous rhetoric and damaging policies. He has fawned over Russian President Vladimir Putin and empowered Russia’s increasingly aggressive behavior. He has wavered on our commitment to NATO, gratuitously escalated arguments with China and Mexico, and questioned the reality of climate change. And his executive order barring citizens from seven Muslim-majority countries from traveling to the United States undermines our values and plays into the hands of ISIS and other enemies.   The Secretary of State must play a crucial role in maintaining relationships between the United States and our allies around the world. Mr. Trump’s statements and actions highlight the need for a Secretary of State who will push back against President Trump’s worst impulses – but nothing in Mr. Tillerson’s record indicates he’ll offer that much-needed balance.   Given Russia’s interference with U.S. elections and Russia’s increased provocation of our allies, we need to be able to rely on our Secretary of State to advance U.S. interests above all. Mr. Tillerson’s close relationship with Vladimir Putin casts doubt on his ability and inclination to pursue additional sanctions as necessary and on the quality of advice that he will give the President.   I am also concerned that Mr. Tillerson does not seem to view human rights as a critical issue for the State Department. In addition to refusing to condemn Russian and Syrian atrocities as war crimes, he did not condemn Philippine President Duterte’s extrajudicial killings. This is particularly disturbing, as President Duterte has alleged that President Trump approves of his actions. Mr. Tillerson’s lack of focus on human rights and the rule of law indicate that he seems not to appreciate the role of America in the world.   Finally, I seriously question Mr. Tillerson’s commitment to working with our allies and cosigners of the Paris Climate Agreement to confront one of our greatest global challenges.   Given his extensive ties to Russia and questionable commitment to advancing human rights and combatting climate change, I do not believe that Mr. Tillerson is the right person for this job.

Donald Trump’s unqualified and unprepared cabinet nominees like Betsy DeVos, coupled with aides like Steve Bannon who appeal to the very worst of Trump’s impulsive and divisive character, are a serious cause for concern. Our President wakes up every day and tweets whatever pops into his head with no regard for the consequences and no one to keep him in check. But the good news is that the American people are energized and engaged – they are flooding the phone lines on Capitol Hill because they are deeply worried about the direction Donald Trump is taking our country.

As we commemorate Black History Month, I’m spotlighting some pioneering Marylanders who have made a lasting impact on our nation. Baltimore's Enoch Pratt Free Library was a great resource for gathering important information about these historic figures.  Verda Welcome (1907-1990) was a civil rights activists, public school teacher, and the first African-American woman in the country to become a state senator. Welcome moved to Maryland in 1929 to attend Coppin Normal School, where she received a teaching certificate. She continued her education at Morgan State College, and New York University graduate school. Welcome returned to Maryland and served as a Baltimore City public school teacher for more than 10 years. She quickly became active in her local community leading the fight to lower racial barriers. Driven by her desire to advance equal rights and eliminate discrimination against African-Americans, she was elected to the Maryland House of Delegates and then the Maryland State Senate. Some of her many notable achievements included repealing Maryland interracial laws, changing Morgan State College to Morgan State University, resulting in significantly increased funding, and prohibiting discrimination in public accommodations.

The chaos created by Donald Trump’s dangerous executive order continues, and children with cancer are some of its unfortunate victims. This ill-conceived policy is emboldening our enemies while innocent lives hang in the balance. I’ve introduced legislation to stop the executive order from being implemented. We need Republican leaders who recognize how dangerous this policy is to speak up, because our values and security are at risk.
"Voters should remind Republican senators that if they surrender to Mr. Trump on appointees so clearly unfit, they will be relinquishing a historic obligation and tarnishing themselves.”

The role of the U.S. Senate is to advance the agenda of the public good -- not the agenda of ExxonMobil.    That's why it’s outrageous that the Senate today repealed bipartisan anti-corruption and investor-protection measures applying to oil and gas companies -- just days after the Senate voted to confirm Rex Tillerson, former CEO of ExxonMobil, to be Secretary of State.   There is no logical reason to go against international norms and repeal a bipartisan rule supported by much of the energy industry itself, investors, and advocates for transparency and government reform – all to appease the interests of ExxonMobil and its big-oil friends.

This morning, we continued to hold the floor to speak out against the confirmation of Betsy DeVos. She has shown a lack of awareness about our nation’s commitment to equal rights for children with disabilities. She has spent much of her career working to divert taxpayer resources away from public schools. And her lack of seriousness in response to a question about guns in schools it outright disturbing.

The movement to resist President Trump and his dangerous policies is strong, organic, and growing. People are deeply concerned with the direction he’s taking our country, and we are turning that concern into a powerful movement. While the White House is spewing ‘alternative facts’ and disparaging those who disagree with them, our resolve to fight for the safety and character of our nation only grows stronger.

I do not believe Senator Sessions will be a fighter for those who are less powerful and those who are left out. Nothing in his record indicates he’ll be a warrior for justice – or an independent check on a president who shows open disdain for the independence of the judicial branch. We need an Attorney General who will stand up for the law and for equal justice for every American, and I cannot support Senator Sessions for a position that is so vital to our democracy.

As we commemorate Black History Month, I’m spotlighting some pioneering Marylanders who have made a lasting impact on our nation. Baltimore's Enoch Pratt Free Library was a great resource for gathering important information about these historic figures.  Decatur Dorsey (1836-1891) was among the first African Americans to be awarded the Medal of Honor for heroic actions during the Civil War. Dorsey was born into slavery where he worked for a land baron in Howard County, Maryland. After he was freed, he enlisted in the Union Army and joined Baltimore’s 39th U.S. Colored Infantry. During the Battle of the Crater in Petersburg, VA, Dorsey rallied his troops and led a successful charge against a heavily fortified Confederate encampment, which resulted in the capture of more than 200 enemy soldiers. #BlackHistoryMonth

I am proud to join with Senator Gillibrand and 26 of my colleagues to introduce the Family and Medical Insurance Leave Act (FAMILY Act) which would create a national fund to help meet the needs of workers who are forced to leave their jobs to address a serious personal or family health issue. The FAMILY Act would create a self-sustaining family insurance program for all workers – young and elderly, single and married, and men and women, regardless of the size of their employer. It would cost only as much as a cup of coffee per week and would provide up to 66 percent wage-replacement for 12 weeks in the event of a serious personal or family medical emergency. American workers deserve to have added economic security for difficult times when they need it most. This legislation is an important step in that direction.

Today I spoke on the Senate floor to oppose the nomination of Rep. Tom Price to serve as Secretary of Health and Human Services. Among his many disqualifications is his work to dismantle the Affordable Care Act. His ‘repeal and run’ plan would harm millions of Marylanders – including those living in rural parts of our state. Rural hospitals across Maryland have told me that repealing the ACA without a replacement would be absolutely devastating to their ability to provide quality health care. I’m fighting to protect health care for all Marylanders, and I cannot support Rep. Price to serve as HHS Secretary.

Michael Flynn was already a poor choice to be National Security Adviser – his past comments disparaging the entire religion of Islam embolden ISIS and make our nation less safe. He should be fired if he lied to the Vice President and the American people.

Today I will vote NO on Donald Trump's nominee for Secretary of the Treasury -- Steve Mnuchin. We need a Treasury Secretary who we can trust to do what’s best for American taxpayers, workers, and homeowners. Steve Mnuchin does not meet that test.       Mnuchin has said that his "number one priority" is to roll back Wall Street regulations (Dodd-Frank) that were enacted to prevent taxpayers from having to bail out gambling on Wall Street. We can't afford a system that privatizes massive gains for a few on Wall Street, but socializes the losses on the backs of taxpayers and Main Street. In addition, his bank, OneWest, engaged in aggressive predatory lending, profiting off of the misery of others. They became known as a 'foreclosure machine' because they evicted homeowners instead of working with struggling Americans to keep a roof over their heads. I heard heartbreaking testimony from the victims of these schemes. We need leaders focused on building an economy that works for all, not an economy that works for the few at the expense of the many.

We must have a full investigation into General Flynn and the Trump campaign’s ties to the Russian government both before and after the election. This is not a question of trust between President Trump and his inner circle – it’s a question of trust for the American people. At every turn, this Administration has been misleading the public and deflecting blame. The firing of General Flynn raises more questions than it answered. We know that the Russian government intervened in our election to support Donald Trump. The General Flynn debacle underscores the need for a full public accounting of this story from start to finish.

Russia’s active involvement in influencing the 2016 presidential election was an attack on our democracy. Even before General Flynn was forced to resign in scandal, I joined with Senator Cardin and others to introduce legislation to establish a commission to thoroughly investigate Russia’s actions. The new revelations that members of the Trump team were engaged in repeated contact with Russian intelligence during the campaign — despite denials from Donald Trump himself — should be deeply disturbing to all Americans, regardless of political party. The credibility of President Trump and his administration now rests on conducting a thorough investigation into these issues.   There is no time to waste. Both our national security and the integrity of our democracy are at stake.

Here we go again... The latest in a long line of ignominious Trump nominations. Tomorrow the Senate will vote on the confirmation of Scott Pruitt to lead the Environmental Protection Agency. Pruitt has spent his career attacking the EPA and its mission to protect our air, water, and vital ecosystems like our beloved Chesapeake Bay. You don't ask a fox to guard the hen house. Tomorrow morning at 9 am I will be speaking on the floor against this nomination and voting NO on Mr. Pruitt.

Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt has shown willful ignorance about climate change. He has sided with big-money special interests that pollute our environment and tried to stop protections for the Chesapeake Bay. And now, Washington Republicans want to force a vote on his confirmation to be the next EPA Administrator before we have the chance to see the 3,000 emails that a judge has required to be provided to the public next week. We have an obligation to the American people to review those emails, and I urge all Senators to vote no on Mr. Pruitt’s confirmation today.

Despite all the talk during the campaign, the Trump Administration has yet to unveil a proposal to modernize America’s infrastructure — including our roads, bridges, transit, rail, ports, broadband, clean energy networks and water systems.     Both in the House and now in the Senate, I have joined with my Democratic colleagues to present comprehensive infrastructure plans to make us more competitive in the 21st Century and put more Americans to work in good paying jobs. It is time for both the Administration and Congressional Republicans to join us in this effort. I am concerned by reports that the Trump/Republican plan will be nothing more than large tax breaks for Wall Street investors.   This week I was pleased to visit the Port of Baltimore and meet with many of the men and women who work there. The Port is a huge economic engine for our state and generates thousands of good paying jobs. The future growth and success of the Port will depend on substantial private and public investments. There is no time to waste – let’s get to work right now building a strong economic future for our state and nation.

President Trump has vowed to defund Planned Parenthood, and Congressional Republicans are aiming to send a bill to his desk. Before they call a vote, these lawmakers need to seriously consider the devastating impact on health that defunding Planned Parenthood would have. They don’t need to look any further than Planned Parenthood of Maryland's Baltimore Health Clinic, where I was pleased to meet with their hardworking staff, dedicated volunteers, and young women who are healthy today because of the affordable health services Planned Parenthood provides. Across Maryland, Planned Parenthood served over 40,000 people – men and women – in the last year alone. I’m fighting to protect access to lifesaving services like cancer screenings, STI testing and treatment, and preventive care. When many women have nowhere else to turn for affordable care, Planned Parenthood is there for them. That's why I stand with Planned Parenthood.

I toured Health Care for the Homeless in Baltimore to learn more about their invaluable work caring for Marylanders in need. The Affordable Care Act has allowed them to treat more patients, create jobs in the community, and provide lifesaving services to individuals looking to get healthy and get ahead. If Congressional Republicans succeed in their obsession to repeal the ACA, our communities throughout Maryland -- urban and rural areas alike -- will be sicker and less prosperous. We must improve the ACA, not destroy it. I’ll continue to fight to ensure every Marylander has access to quality, affordable care.

I was proud to join students and educators at the University of Maryland Eastern Shore (UMES) for a special Black History Month event to honor Maryland native Harriet Tubman and announce new legislation to bring Tubman's statute to the halls of the U.S. Capitol. A native of Dorchester County, Tubman's heroic efforts as a conductor on the Underground Railroad to help slaves escape to freedom is a legacy that should be celebrated alongside that of other great Americans honored in the Capitol. It is as important as ever today to remember the courageous acts of individual Americans who stand up for freedom and justice.

The news that the Justice Department has reversed its previous position opposing Texas’ discriminatory voter ID law is a chilling sign of what we can expect in the Trump/Sessions era when it comes to standing up for voting rights. Those of us who opposed Jeff Sessions' nomination are sadly not surprised by this troubling news. We now have an Attorney General and a President who are not willing to stand up for the fundamental right of every American to vote. Our fight to protect our democracy and advance voting rights can and must continue with vigilance.

In Maryland and across the country, Americans are being threatened and attacked for what they believe and where they are from. There’s no doubt that this epidemic of anti-Semitism and racism stems from the so-called leaders who have emboldened those who preach hate and stoke fear. We will not waver in our commitment to protect religious freedom in America, and we will always stand against hate wherever it rears its ugly head.

Few people are as devoted to the continuation of exploration and discovery than Bill Nye The Science Guy, and we sat down to discuss the need for our nation to maintain its leadership in this vital area. While we disagreed on one important issue – his lack of enthusiasm for the Baltimore Orioles – we found common ground around the immense value in supporting agencies like NASA Goddard Space Flight Center and Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory in my home state of Maryland, as well as research institutions across the country. The budget blueprint Donald Trump will outline in his speech to Congress tonight is expected be bad news for domestic priorities like science and research. American jobs, prestige, and leadership are on the line – not to mention the health of our planet. We must fight to maintain and expand our commitment to science.

As he said tonight, President Trump has had a busy first month in office – but his actions have not kept his promises to put working families first.   He has failed to put forward an economic plan or offer a concrete proposal for sustained job creation. And he failed to drain the swamp in Washington, instead installing Wall Street billionaires in his Cabinet and failing to address serious questions about his campaign’s relationship – and his personal business ties – with Russia.  In fact, the President’s first actions have been at odds with many of the values we hold dear as a nation. His budget blueprint threatens important domestic priorities – from supporting public schools, to providing small business loans to entrepreneurs, to making college more affordable, to investing in lifesaving research, to keeping our air and water clean. He has issued an executive order that made it harder for people to afford a mortgage, opposed efforts to provide middle-class Americans overtime pay, and taken steps to end efforts to better protect Americans’ retirement savings from abusive practices. And he has made our nation less safe by insulting our allies, fawning over our adversaries, and playing into the hands of ISIS and other enemies.   Tonight President Trump presented proposals that will be greeted with great optimism by big-money, corporate special interests – but working families are losing out in his new Administration. I hope that, moving forward, Mr. Trump puts aside the divisive campaign rhetoric and works with Democrats to create good-paying jobs, invest in our nation’s infrastructure, and strengthen our schools and our job training programs.

President Trump stuck to his script last night on issues like child care, infrastructure and education, but we haven’t seen any administration proposals to back up his statements. To the contrary, the expected White House budget would cut funding for these priorities. And in areas like health care, the environment, and financial oversight, Team Trump has already proven they are bent on destroying and dismantling current safeguards.   We need to watch actions, not words.

The Attorney General holds a special position as top law enforcement officer in our country. Anyone serving in that position must have the confidence of the American people to be an honest and independent broker who protects the fundamentals of our democracy. In failing to tell the truth – under oath – about his conversations with Russia at a time when so many questions surround Moscow’s effort to influence our elections and the nature of their relationship to individuals in the Trump Administration, it is clear that Attorney General Sessions is no longer able to meet that standard and must resign.  Additionally, Mr. Sessions should immediately be called to appear before the Senate Judiciary Committee under oath so we can determine exactly how many conversations took place, when they happened, and what was discussed. This public accounting is essential to restoring the integrity of the Judiciary Committee process in the light of the Attorney General’s misleading statements.  We must act decisively to ensure that the American people have full faith and confidence in the institutions of our democracy that are charged with protecting their rights.

Today I was proud to join with the  National Treasury Employees Union (NTEU) and stand up for all of our public servants who work tirelessly every day to make our government work for the American people — conducting critical medical research, defending us from cyber attacks, protecting our environment, caring for our veterans, providing access to Social Security and Medicare, and much, much more. I will fight every day to make sure that they get the fair treatment they deserve and protect them against any political retribution for doing their jobs for the American people.

The budget cuts proposed by the Trump Administration and its EPA-suing EPA Administrator, Scott Pruitt, could seriously damage our efforts to clean up the Chesapeake Bay and the jobs that depend on it -- from the watermen to the tourism and boating industries. This should be a wake-up call to every Marylander -- and every American -- who cares about clean water and the jobs that rely on healthy ecosystems.    The Chesapeake Bay is a national treasure and a key lifeline for Maryland's economy. As a member of the Senate Budget, Appropriations, and Agriculture Committees, one of my top priorities is making sure that Maryland has the tools and resources it needs to protect the Bay. Together, we must stand against the Trump Administration’s proposals that will harm the Bay and the jobs that depend on keeping it healthy.

The revised executive order will weaken, not strengthen, the security of Americans by playing into the hands of our enemies. President Trump has engaged in fear-mongering about visitors and refugees from these six countries, and this executive order is now a fake solution to the real security issues we face. We do face real threats from ISIS and need to redouble our efforts to destroy them. Unfortunately, this executive order will hinder,  not help, that mission.

This is a scary moment for our country because clearly we have a White House and a President who are not reality based. This Administration has been trying to interfere with the Russia investigation, and now you have the President making outrageous unsubstantiated allegations. If they've got nothing to hide, they've got nothing to fear. They should just put all the information out there -- including the President’s tax returns.

As we mark International Women’s Day -- and women across the country are participating in a 'Day Without Women' -- I want to recognize the role of the many smart, strong, accomplished, and dedicated women in my own life, starting with my wife and daughter. The majority of my senior staff are also women, and my Senate office could not serve Marylanders without their hard work and critical contributions. My female colleagues in the Senate are among the most effective in this body. I have also worked and continue to work daily with visionary women leaders across the state of Maryland in every field and community who are dedicated to making our state and world a better place for all. Together we are committed to being 'bold for change’ today and every day.

Trumpcare is not a replacement for Obamacare – it is a joke. If Donald Trump negotiated this plan, it’s clear that he was negotiating on behalf of the millionaires and billionaires in his cabinet, and for the insurance companies that would get a tax break for the multi-million dollar bonuses they pay their CEOs. He was NOT negotiating for everyday Americans, and certainly not for older Americans or people with disabilities who have come out strongly against this bill. We need a full, informed debate on Trumpcare. If we get it, I’m confident it will be defeated.

Trumpcare is a betrayal of the promises Donald Trump made during the campaign to Americans struggling to get by. It’s a $600 billion tax break for the wealthiest in our nation, while everyone else takes it on the chin. It lets insurance companies write off multi-million dollar bonuses for their CEOs. It will rip access to insurance away from millions of Americans, and rural hospitals in Maryland would be devastated.   Americans are tired of millionaires and billionaires like those in Trump’s cabinet rigging the system to help the rich get richer. The responsibility to provide advice and consent on Supreme Court nominees is one of the most important constitutional powers granted to the U.S. Senate. After carefully evaluating Neil Gorsuch’s record and his testimony before the Judiciary Committee, I have concluded that he applies a cramped reading of the law and consistently sides with powerful special interests against the rights of individuals, workers, and consumers. When he had an opportunity during the hearings to clarify that bias, he chose instead to evade questions and answered with platitudes, not substance. While he is undoubtedly a skilled lawyer, his bias in favor of corporate power, coupled with his refusal to answer reasonable questions, lead me to conclude that he falls outside the judicial mainstream. The case that the Supreme Court decided in the middle of his hearing illustrates the point: The current Supreme Court Justices unanimously rejected his reasoning against the right of individuals with disabilities to receive an equal education. For all these reasons, I will oppose his nomination.  After the Senate’s unprecedented abdication of constitutional responsibility with respect to the Garland nomination, we must begin to restore faith in the Supreme Court. That requires a nominee who is widely viewed to be an impartial administrator of justice—someone who is truly in the mainstream and who can earn the support of at least 60 senators. I will insist that this nominee be held to that standard.  The decisions of the nine individuals with lifetime appointments to the Supreme Court have a direct impact on who we are as Americans and the future of our democracy. We have witnessed a series of 5-to-4 decisions that shape the character of our nation. We have seen the Court run roughshod over large majorities in the Congress to gut an important provision of the Voting Rights Act. In Citizens United, we watched the Court trample over statutes and ample Supreme Court precedent to empower corporations to spend unlimited amounts of money to elect representatives who will do their bidding. And a single vote gave individuals the right to marry the person they love.  With so much at stake, we need a nominee who can give the country confidence that he or she will be impartial. Donald Trump, however, demanded the opposite. He established a litmus test for his nominee, insisting on someone who opposed a woman’s right to reproductive choice and someone who would satisfy the National Rifle Association. He then contracted out the process to a group of right-wing organizations to compose a list of names—and he dutifully selected Gorsuch from their list. Given that process, it is not surprising that Gorsuch falls outside the judicial mainstream.

The nine justices with lifetime appointments to the Supreme Court help shape the character of our country and the future of our democracy—from ensuring folks the right to vote to determine whether corporations can spend unlimited amounts of money trying to buy elections, to giving a person the right to marry who they love. The American people should have confidence that the next justice on the highest court in the land will make impartial, unbiased, decisions. And after careful evaluation of Judge Gorsuch’s record and testimony, I have concluded that he does not pass that bar.   He has consistently sided with powerful special interest against the rights of individuals, workers, and consumers. That is probably not surprising given that Donald Trump picked him off a list presented by right-wing interest groups and established a litmus test, saying that he wanted someone who does not support women’s reproductive freedom and would make the National Rifle Association happy. Now, more than ever, we need somebody on the Court who will be an impartial administrator of justice—someone who is truly in the mainstream and who can earn the support of at least 60 senators. Neil Gorsuch is not that person.

That’s simply reckless and irresponsible, people’s lives are on the line.

Unless there is a public safety rationale, it is outrageous that airlines can forcibly remove passengers that have boarded their flights.   That’s why I am proposing legislation to prohibit that conduct. Instead of ejecting passengers, airlines would be required to provide sufficient financial incentives to encourage passengers to voluntarily deplane.   It’s time airlines start treating people like customers, not cargo.

Donald Trump is the first President in 40 years to refuse to release his tax returns. He is also the first President to profit while in office from an extensive global real estate empire and other business interests that have raised potentially dangerous conflicts of interest. Trump has proposed a tax plan that will give massive tax breaks to billionaires like himself—another potential conflict of interest.  President Trump, the American people need to know if you are putting your private interests before the country’s interest. Americans deserve transparency and accountability.   If you have nothing to hide, you have nothing to fear. Release your taxes. What are you hiding?

Last week, Donald Trump threatened to defund a critical part of the Affordable Care Act so he can free up budgetary space for his tax plan that gives a huge tax cut to the top 1%.   My Democratic colleagues and I have said time and again that we would work with Trump to improve the ACA, yet he refuses to give us a call. Instead, he is openly threatening to deny tens of millions of Americans what is often life-saving access to affordable care.    Donald Trump should stop using millions of Americans as human shields to extract tax breaks for the super rich. Instead of tweeting, he should pick up the phone. We can make improvements by, among other measures, enacting a public option and reducing the price of prescription drugs.

Today’s news brings more alarming information about the consequences of human-caused climate change.   Climate deniers need to accept the facts that are in plain sight. Governments have a critical responsibility to take the measures necessary to reduce the harmful impact on our communities here in Maryland and around the world.

This Thursday at 7pm, I’ll be attending a town hall hosted by the Baltimore Indivisible Coalition at the War Memorial Building in Baltimore with Congressman Elijah Cummings, Congressman John Sarbanes, and Congressman Dutch Ruppersberger.   I am eager to take your questions and share ideas to move our country forward, together. Join me this Thursday and get the details below:

International high stakes diplomacy is often likened to a tough high-wire act. Success involves a delicate combination of sticks, carrots, and engagement—but more than anything else it requires credibility.  Credibility in your promises and in your threats. This latest saga over which way U.S. Navy aircraft carriers were sailing—towards the North Korean peninsula as a sign of U.S. force (as the White House stated), or away from the region (as actual photos have proven to be the case)— demonstrates an inexplicable lack of coordination in our national security policy at a critical moment.  It confirms our ongoing concern that the Trump team is not up to the challenging task ahead. And it reinforces the need for close and regular consultations with the Congress as our country addresses the dangerous issues surrounding North Korea’s behavior in the international community. We can’t afford to get this wrong.

Some of my fondest memories have been in our national parks―exploring, fishing, and hiking with my family. This weekend during National Parks Week, admission is free to any national park so more people can get outside to see Maryland’s vast beauty.   From Assateague Island to the C&O canal, #FindYourPark and start exploring → t.co/mHaRkwz3Ob
