Thanks to everyone who came out to Indivisible Baltimore’s town hall last night. This is what a healthy democracy is all about when you’ve got citizens who are informed, engaged, and advocating for issues that matter most to them. Glad to have the opportunity to listen and answer your thoughtful questions about how we can fight together for Maryland’s families.   Do you have a question that wasn’t answered? Or if you weren’t able to watch last night, I still want to hear from you! Drop your questions in the comments below and I’ll try to answer them this weekend, right here on Facebook.

The United States is a world leader in innovative research, and I’m proud to say much of that work takes place in Maryland. We are home to over 50 science and research institutions and agencies, from NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center to the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), the Applied Physics Laboratory at Johns Hopkins University and many others.  I will continue fighting every day to support science, oppose climate denial, and advance critical research and innovation taking place in Maryland and across our country that benefits each of us, our planet, and future generations.  On #EarthDay, I can’t think of a better way to spend the day than to join thousands of Americans to stand up for human progress.

It was great seeing democracy in action last week when close to 1,000 Marylanders showed up for the town hall hosted by Indivisible Baltimore. For those who weren’t able to attend, I asked folks to share their concerns, thoughts, and questions with me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.    I received a great response, and below are answers to several of them. I look forward to continuing the conversation about how we can work together to fight for Maryland's families.

While working Americans struggle to make ends meet and support themselves and their families on stagnant wages, President Trump wants to shift funds from domestic priorities to foot the bill for a $70 billion wall on our southern border—the same wall that Trump assured us repeatedly Mexico would pay for.   The best way to make America strong is to help Americans prosper. An ineffective wall paid for by taxpayers isn't the way to get there.

Far too many Americans are working harder but still feel stuck in place, as the very wealthy continue to prosper. It’s a national scandal that in America today, you can work full-time—and upwards of 40, 50 or 60 hours a week—and still fall below the federal poverty level.  Our minimum wage should be a living wage. That’s why today I’m proud to join Patty Murray​ and Bernie Sanders to cosponsor a new bill that will raise the minimum wage to $15 by 2024. Raising the minimum wage will help over 41 million Americans, and it’s an important first step toward leveling the playing field so hardworking Marylanders have a chance to get ahead.

Since Donald Trump was sworn in, his policy decisions have been lousy for working Americans but fantastic for his business model. His new tax plan follows a similar trend: Windfall tax cuts for large corporations and companies like his at the expense of everyone else. His huge corporate tax cuts will balloon the federal debt which, in turn, will have to be paid for by working Americans, and our children and grandchildren.    Our tax system is already stacked in favor of those who make money off of money, and against those who earn paychecks through hard work—and the Trump plan will make it even worse.   We must even the playing field for hardworking Americans and put forward a comprehensive economic plan to help every American get ahead, not just the wealthy few. That’s why I’m cosponsoring Senator Sheldon Whitehouse's Paying a Fair Share Act, which will ensure that the super-wealthy pay their fair share and reduce the debt burden on working Americans.

In the United States, We the People decide who holds the highest seats of power, not foreign governments. I’m fighting side-by-side with my colleagues in the Senate to request that Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein appoints an independent prosecutor to investigate Russia’s interference in our election. We need a comprehensive and impartial investigation, and nothing less. Because—at the end of the day—this is about the fundamental nature of our democracy, not about party politics. bit.ly/2qjPtkF

Tomorrow marks President Trump’s hundredth day in office. It’s no surprise that Trump has accomplished very little, but he’s also broken a countless number of promises to the same voters who have desperately counted on him to look out for their best economic interests. In fact, most of Trump’s Presidency has been entirely one of theatrics, not of substance, where he shows himself as a tweeter, not a leader.  Which is why I’m joining Senator Chuck Schumer, House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, Congressman Hakeem Jeffries, Congressman John Yarmuth (KY-3), and Congresswoman Barbara Lee to hold President Trump accountable for his broken promises. Tune in:

Today, I met the Maryland teacher of the year: Sia Kyriakakos from Baltimore. She told me, “Teaching art isn’t only about color and lines; it’s about equity of knowledge and opening a world of possibilities to our students.” The outcome of the relationships Sia builds with her students are a result of some of the most admirable human virtues—courage, passion, resilience, and perseverance.   Maryland’s teachers and educators are some of the best in the nation. But you don’t have to just take my word for it: This week U.S. News and World Report announced that  some of Maryland high schools have been ranked the best in the nation for the third year in a row! I am very proud of Maryland parents, teachers, and educators like Sia whose work helps spark the curiosity of our students and prepares them to compete on the global stage. Now let’s not sit on our laurels, let’s continue to work together to ensure that every student gets a first rate education.

Dear President Trump, on your 100th day in office, Senator Tammy Duckworth and I have a simple message for you: Stop breaking your promises to American families. We need real, substantive action not empty rhetoric.

I’ve heard from people from all across Maryland who are deeply concerned about the harmful impact climate change is having in our communities right now. One of those constituents is Caitlin, a fifth grader from Fallston. Like Caitlin, we must all continue to speak out and make our voices heard. If we don't address this real and current danger, our economy, national security, public health, and environment will all suffer irreparable harm. As many of us head to the People's Climate Movement today, I urge you to share your story about how climate change has impacted your community so we can keep putting pressure on climate deniers. It's up to all of us.

✕  The promise of reliable health care: Broken.  ✕  The promise to help working Americans: Broken.  ✕  The promise of promoting good-paying jobs: Broken.  ✕  The promise of fixing America’s crumbling infrastructure: Broken.  ✕  The promise to make higher education affordable: Broken. ✕  The promise to help rural America: Broken.   And that's only the first 100 days. As we move into the next 100 days, we all must continue to hold him accountable and stand up for our American values.

Despite President Trump’s attempt to cut vital funding in his budget for key infrastructure projects, and environmental, health and educational programs, the American people ultimately proved victorious. Last night, we reached an agreement to keep the government funded, protecting essential programs for Marylanders and ensuring that the American people wouldn’t have to foot the bill for “the wall.”  This included funding for key projects like the Purple Line, the Chesapeake Bay Program, NASA Goddard’s very own PACE Mission, as well as an additional $2 billion for the NIH. This is very good news for Marylanders.

Thank you, Jimmy Kimmel, for speaking out and courageously sharing your son Billy’s story. You’re right: The United States isn’t a football team, we are one team—and this team shouldn’t be prone to partisan scrimmages about covering Americans with pre-existing conditions. Regardless of party lines, whether you're a Republican, Democrat or Independent, we should all agree that no parent should ever have to decide if they can afford to save their child’s life. A very important and timely message about funding for National Institutes of Health (NIH) and making sure Americans with pre-existing conditions are covered.

Years ago, as a member of the Maryland Senate, I was proud to lead the successful fight against discrimination based on sexual orientation. But I am appalled that today a majority of our states have not extended those same protections. In those states, individuals are at risk of being fired, refused an apartment or mortgage, or denied service at a restaurant based on LGBTQ status. This must change. Everyone should have a fair chance to earn a living and provide for their families no matter who they are or whom they love. Discrimination has no place in this country.   That’s why I am proud to co-sponsor new national legislation to ban discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity in employment, housing, public accommodations, and other areas of law where discrimination is already prohibited for other protected classes. The Equality Act will make clear that LGBTQ Americans are fully protected from discrimination under federal law.

Today the Senate is voting on a measure that will make it harder for Americans to save for retirement. I’m on the Senate floor to fight tooth and nail for Marylanders and others throughout this nation, and ask my Republican colleagues a simple question: Why are you working to strip away access to retirement savings for millions of Americans? Apparently they are willing to deny their constituents access to the 401(k) type plans and retirement vehicles that they enjoy as Senators.    I’m proud that Maryland is one of five states that developed a program to make it easier for millions of residents who don’t have access to employer-based retirement savings programs to save for retirement.  But with one vote, that could be taken away. Let’s stop this madness and do something to help hardworking Americans.

We know the terrible destructive power of nuclear weapons. We know that any miscalculation with the use of nuclear weapons could unleash a nuclear Armageddon. That is why the decision to initiate the first use of nuclear weapons should not be made by the president alone. And that's why I joined Senator Edward J. Markey and my colleagues in the House to champion a bill that requires the president to obtain Congressional approval as part of a Declaration of War before engaging in the first use of nuclear weapons. This legislation is important no matter who is president, but it is especially important now that we have a president who so cavalierly talks and tweets about the the use and spread of nuclear weapons.

The House of Representatives just voted to repeal the Affordable Care Act and threaten the access of health care to tens of millions of Americans. The U.S. Senate Democrats and I will work non-stop to block the destructive anti-healthcare bill in the U.S. Senate.  Share your stories in the comments below on why we cannot afford to rip health care away from 24 million Americans, raise costs for folks with pre-existing conditions, force higher premiums for seniors no matter how healthy they are, and slash Medicaid by over $800 billion while giving a $900 billion tax cut to insurance companies and the top 1% of the richest Americans. Health care is not a privilege, but a fundamental right. It’s time to get to work.

I was honored to stand with the Sandy Hook Ride on Washington at the beginning of their bike ride from Washington, DC to Newtown, Connecticut to fight to end the kind of gun violence that left 26 dead—20 of them children—at Sandy Hook Elementary School.   President Trump said he was moved to action in Syria by the horrible images of dying children he saw on TV. Mr. President, what about the children gunned down in Newtown, and the other children and Americans who are being slaughtered by gun violence every single day right here at home?   Instead of acting to stop the carnage in our own country, Trump recently went to the NRA and offered to do the bidding of the gun lobby. That is a recipe for more—not less—killing in our schools and communities. We need to restore sanity to our gun safety laws and fight back against the effort to loosen conceal-carry laws which would put states like Maryland, which have enacted common sense gun safety reforms, at greater risk. I know in the long run we will overcome. bit.ly/2qF5BON

The Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park revitalization project is a great example of local, state & federal resources coming together to rebuild infrastructure in Western Maryland.  I am very proud to take part in marking the start of this history making project! Once the aqueduct is complete, Williamsport will be the only place on the continent where visitors can ride boats across an aqueduct and through a working canal lock. Tune in as I speak at the groundbreaking to celebrate the restoration of the Conococheague Aqueduct.

Today, on National Foreign Service Day, I want to honor our foreign service officers, who work tirelessly for our country—in nearly 300 embassies, consulates, and diplomatic missions around the world. I also want to pay tribute to the diplomats who’ve lost their lives while serving our country. These men and women help keep America safe through their work to protect our national security by resolving conflicts in ways that keep America from going to war. They are also on the front lines of our efforts to promote the ideals of democracy, human rights, liberty, opportunity and equality around the world.

When President Trump released his budget plan last month, I immediately began to receive phone calls, emails, tweets and comments online from concerned Marylanders—and for good reason. The budget that the Trump Administration put forward would have been a disaster for our state. But, we fought back and together we secured important investments in Maryland and our nation’s future. I’m pleased to report that this week we passed a budget plan that not only avoids a government shutdown but also is a big win for Marylanders: It includes funding for key priorities like the Chesapeake Bay Program, medical research at the NIH, operations at the Port of Baltimore, Community Development Block Grants for local economic development, the Purple Line transit system, WMATA, the Appalachian Regional Commission (ARC), and important rural programs.

Good news: Today a new report from the University of Maryland showed the overall health of the Chesapeake Bay is improving for the second-straight year. While there’s still much more work to do, this demonstrates the importance of sustained federal funding for our Bay cleanup efforts. I’m pleased to say that just last week Congress passed a budget plan that included funding for the Chesapeake Bay Program. The Trump Administration budget proposes to eliminate funding for this vital program in the coming fiscal year, staring October 1st. That would undermine our progress.   I look forward to working on a bipartisan basis to defeat the Trump budget cuts so we can continue to improve the health of the Bay. The Bay is not only a natural treasure, it is vital to our tourism and boating industries, as well as the watermen and others whose livelihood depends on the bounty of a healthy Bay.

I’m headed to the floor to speak about why the Republican’s health care plan would be devastating to Marylanders. We cannot afford to let this unconscionable plan pass the U.S. Senate.  The Republicans’ health care bill is rotten at its core. Their plan cuts $880 billion from Medicaid and Medicare just so they can transfer that money back to the wealthiest and corporate special interests. You can’t fix something that’s already broken—especially when their first bill was only supported by 17% of Americans.  To the American people: Beware of anyone who says they can make a meaningful change to TrumpCare—or as I like to call it wealthcare—when it’s only a cosmetic change that attempts to provide political cover at the expense of everyday Americans. It’s time to stop playing games with the lives of over 24 million Americans.

President Trump's firing of FBI Director James Comey has the foul stench of an attempt to stop an ongoing investigation into collusion between the Trump campaign and the Russians. This has created a crisis of confidence in our Justice Department. While I’ve long had concerns about Director Comey, it’s shocking that the Justice Department and the White House would blatantly interfere in an ongoing and very active investigation. This is yet another reason why we need a special prosecutor to take over the investigation immediately.

Today I’m joining U.S. Senate Democrats to discuss the real-life impacts Trumpcare would have on millions of Americans. Carol Fisher Hardaway from Salisbury is one Marylander whose health care would be threatened. She is a part-time substitute teacher who was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis in 1990 and relies on Medicaid. With the Republicans’ health care bill cutting Medicaid and Medicare by $839 billion, Carol is just one of tens of thousands of Marylanders whose affordable health care coverage would disappear. Tune in as we discuss why it’s time to fight back against all those who are willing to risk the lives of Americans just so they can provide a huge tax break to the very wealthy and corporate special interests.
Even the youngest activists can help spur medical research and innovation. Theo, thanks for your hard work to support the STAR Act!

It’s now clear that President Trump fired former FBI Director Comey because he was getting nervous about the Russia investigation.  Earlier the Trump team tried to pin the reason for the firing on Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein but, as suspected, it was Trump all along who made the decision. In this environment, it’s imperative that we have an independent, impartial investigator. We need a special prosecutor to handle this investigation.  Trump and his Administration ought to learn from our history—after all, President Nixon tried the "You're Fired" approach to obstructing the truth and it did not end well for him.

We’re now fighting against the threat of Trumpcare 2.0, which would deny hundreds of thousands of Marylanders access to affordable health care and undermine the stability of our Maryland health care system. Trumpcare 2.0 — or what I like to call “wealthcare”— cuts Medicaid and Medicare by $880 billion while providing a huge windfall tax break to insurance companies and the wealthiest people in America. Over 70 million Americans rely on Medicaid’s vital services that extend opportunity and healthy living, especially the 15 million Americans with disabilities. Thank you to all the Marylanders who have shared their concerns and stories with my me and my Senate colleagues. I’m fighting like hell to preserve Medicaid for the millions of people like Carol from Silver Spring, who relies on Medicaid for her son with autism, and like Mark from Columbia, a 28-year-old with multiple sclerosis who needs 24-hour care. For these reasons and the millions of others in Maryland and across this country, we will keep fighting.

This Mother’s Day weekend, I’m reminded of all of the mothers who have shared their heartbreaking and gut-wrenching stories about how they have had to practically give up everything just so they can afford health care for their children. For moms like Katie from Westminster, whose 2-year-old daughter Jane was born with multiple pre-existing conditions, her child's life would quite literally be on the line without adequate access to health care.   It’s time we put Americans’ right to affordable health care above partisan politics. Regardless of party lines, whether you're a Republican, Democrat or Independent, we should all agree that no parent should ever have to decide if they can afford to save their child’s life. The lives of children across Maryland, like Jane, are on the line.

We cannot afford to turn our backs on the millions of Marylanders who need lifesaving health care. Having a pre-existing condition isn’t a choice and life-saving care shouldn’t be a privilege reserved for a few. Let’s continue telling our stories about why Marylanders with pre-existing conditions—like asthma, diabetes, or any other condition—need access to affordable care.

Last night, the Washington Post reported that President Trump leaked highly classified code word information regarding our fight against ISIS to the Russian Foreign Minister and Russian Ambassador. Despite initial denials, the President's tweet today indicates that he divulged classified information. As with the Comey firing, the story keeps shifting. The bottom line is this: the fact that the President feels the need to brag to the Russians by revealing secret information sets a very dangerous precedent for our country and could put lives at risk. If the President can't keep a secret, our friends and allies will be scared to share vital information with us. Compromising critical sources only helps our enemies and hurts our allies.

The series of events that started with the successful Russian attack on our elections continues to plague our institutions and our ability to govern. The developments that began last week with the firing of FBI Director Jim Comey have brought this crisis to a totally new level. Our country was founded on the principle that we are a nation of laws and that no one—not even a President—is above the law. We must proceed with a thorough investigation into all the issues that have emerged, including a potential White House cover-up or effort to obstruct the FBI’s Russia investigation. At this moment every sitting Member of Congress, who has sworn to uphold the Constitution, should understand that until this crisis is resolved it weakens America at home and abroad. This is not a time for division. It’s a moment for unity and resolve in preserving our institutions and the rule of law.

Last week I met Carol Hardaway, one of my constituents from Salisbury, Maryland. She gave gut-wrenching testimony about living with multiple sclerosis to me and my colleagues in the Senate. Without the health care she received from the Affordable Care Act and Medicaid expansion, she’d still be living in a country where every insurer she called would laugh at her, simply because she has several pre-existing conditions. Trumpcare would take us back to that time. It cuts Medicaid and Medicare by $880 billion and would make health care unaffordable for the 2.6 million Marylanders with pre-existing conditions—just so Republicans can provide a huge windfall tax break to insurance companies and the wealthiest people in America.   I’m grateful for Marylanders, like Carol, who have courageously shared their stories. At the end of the day, these personal testimonials are what will turn the tide in favor of affordable health care for all Americans. So for Carol, and millions of others around the country, let’s continue to make our voices heard and ”fight like hell.” http://bit.ly/2qsuLlV

Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein made the right decision by appointing a special counsel. He determined that the law and circumstances demanded this action despite White House opposition. Thanks to all who called upon him to do the right thing for the country. Now, we need to make sure the special counsel has the resources to uncover the truth about potential collusion between the Trump campaign and the Russians. Congress must also do its job and vote to establish a non-partisan commission to provide the American public with a full picture of the Russian interference in our elections so we can take all necessary measures to protect the integrity of our democracy.
I’m joining Senator Chris Murphy and Senator Richard Blumenthal in exposing just how President Trump and Congressional Republicans’ have been trying to sabotage our health care system. Tune in live:

At a time when many of our communities are experiencing an opioid crisis, we cannot afford to roll back progress and strip away health care that could save thousands of lives. We must treat drug addiction as a health issue, not a criminal justice issue.    I’ve seen first-hand how impactful treatment facilities can be in our fight against opioid and prescription drug abuse. Just last week I visited the Tuerk House in West Baltimore and had the opportunity to meet with patients whose lives were saved by substance abuse treatment.    Unfortunately, the wealth care plan put forward by President Trump and Republicans in Congress would shift billions of dollars in costs for substance use disorders and mental health services to the states and our families. We must stop this plan and I will fight day and night to make sure facilities like Tuerk House have the support they need to help Marylanders.

It’s no surprise that Treasury Secretary Mnuchin has such a difficult time keeping promises, he is President Trump’s appointee, after all. But, back in November, he promised the American people that there would be no tax cuts for the upper class. Yet, the analysis of the Trumpcare tax cuts clearly shows that millionaires will get, on average, $50,000 a year in tax cuts. This totally violates the standard Secretary Mnuchin set forward in November. Secretary Mnuchin can avoid answering my questions as much as he wants to, but I won’t stop asking, writing, and holding the executive branch accountable for their contradictory rhetoric—and you shouldn’t either. Our shared economic prosperity depends on it.

1. President Trump calling anyone a 'nut job’ is quite ironic. 2. The special counsel will be very interested in Trump’s comments to the Russians on Comey’s firing. 3. If Trump has nothing to hide, he has nothing to fear.   Read more → nyti.ms/2pUqZTt
Had a great time throwing out the first pitch at yesterday's Baltimore Orioles game with Senator Ben Cardin. But, maybe we shouldn’t quit our day jobs...

Families in Maryland and across the country deserve certainty about the stability and cost of their health insurance. Unfortunately, the Trump Administration and Congressional Republicans refuse to provide it. Cost-sharing subsidies lower the deductibles, co-pays, and other out-of-pocket costs for those who purchase plans on the exchange. By continuing this uncertainty in the market, President Trump is increasing costs for hardworking Americans. We know our current health care system isn’t perfect, but Republicans would rather blow it up than fix it. It's time for Republicans to end this effort at sabotage and put access to affordable health care before politics.

It’s comical to think that President Trump’s budget is described by his team as “taxpayer first” since it hurts working Americans and puts millionaires first, negating the very promises his campaign was built on. In May 2015, candidate Trump tweeted, “I was the first and only potential GOP candidate to state there will be no cuts to Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid.”   But as we learn more details about the Trump budget today, we begin to understand that it’s simply a tool in the ultimate con game the President has been playing with our country. It represents an all-out assault on our health care system—from staggering cuts to Medicaid to attacks on the bipartisan Children’s Health Insurance Program—leaving kids, veterans, individuals with disabilities, and seniors out in the cold. It also reneges on the pledge not to cut Social Security by cutting Social Security Disability Insurance.    And it doesn’t just stop there: Trump’s budget takes a wrecking ball to vital transportation projects for Maryland like the Purple Line, eliminates programs that help veterans find housing, cuts life-saving treatment from the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and CDC, reverses the progress we’ve made towards protecting our environment and vital resources likes the Chesapeake Bay, and chops rungs off the ladder of opportunity by hacking away at every level of education—from student financial aid, to career and technical education, to after school programs.   In short, the Trump budget afflicts the most vulnerable and comforts the powerful who can fly private jets to places like Mar-a-Lago for the weekend. The Trump budget should really be called, “Millionaire's First, Working People Last.”

I wanted to share my immediate reactions to the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) report with you. This is the smoking gun that shows that TrumpCare 2.0 is all about WealthCare, not health care. It confirms what families in Maryland and across the country already knew: Trumpcare 2.0 is rotten to the core. Congressional Republicans went back to the drawing board, but what they came up with still leaves 23 million more Americans uninsured and cuts Medicaid by $834 billion, while cutting taxes for the rich and powerful. In fact, this bill would take away health care from over 180,000 Marylanders next year alone and increase premiums by $742 in our state.   Millions more will be left with skyrocketing costs and fewer options, because it would allow insurance companies in some states to opt-out of covering essential health benefits and to charge older Americans and people with pre-existing conditions more than under our current health care system.    As Democrats have made clear, we’re ready to work in a bipartisan way to improve the Affordable Care Act—but I will fight tooth and nail to ensure this unconscionable bill does not stand.

The only way the Trump Administration is “balancing” the federal budget is through fraudulent accounting on the backs of millions of working Americans. At today’s budget hearing, I asked President Trump's budget director Mick Mulvaney about their scheme. Watch and share:

Today, at the First Baptist Church of Glenarden, we celebrated the life of Second Lieutenant Richard Wilbur Collins III. Lieutenant Collins, known to friends and family as Richie, was a brave, brilliant, passionate, selfless, and kind person. He had just been commissioned in the U.S. Army and was about to graduate from Bowie State University. His future could not have been brighter when his life was cut short by a hateful act of violence motivated by racism. His selfless and courageous contributions to Maryland and our nation will continue to have a lasting impact on those who knew and loved him, and on the broader community who learned of his tragic, senseless, and unjust death.  As Americans, we have a moral responsibility to make sure that no parent has to wake up in the morning in fear that their child is at risk simply because of the color of their skin. The murder of Lieutenant Collins’  is a terrible reminder that we must act more urgently to confront racism and bigotry in every form, both in Maryland and across the country. If we don’t, we are failing our entire community, including the mothers and fathers of young men like Richie who so desperately want to believe that their country stands with them just as Lieutenant Collin's stood with his country. We must not rest until the perpetrator of this evil act is brought to justice and we stamp out hate in all its forms. We must do better.

As we gather with friends and family this Memorial Day, let’s pause to honor the men and women who have served and given their lives in defense of our great nation. The sacrifices these brave and courageous Americans have made are what makes our freedom possible today. But it’s not enough to simply remember them with words—we need to recommit ourselves to our veterans and the men and women who serve us today to ensure they get the support that a grateful nation can provide.

While the Senate is out of session this week, I wanted to send a quick reminder to my Republican colleagues about the Trumpcare 2.0  bill passed by the House of Representatives: It’s is not enough to make a few cosmetic changes and say, “Look. We made it better!” Trumpcare 2.0 is rotten to its core and will not be mended with a Band-Aid or two.   And last week’s nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) report told us just that. Trumpcare 2.0, just like the earlier version, is really a massive transfer of wealth from working and middle-income Americans to the top 1% in our country and to very powerful special interest groups. Its title really should be the American Wealthcare Act, not the American Health Care Act. For every $1 that goes to cover people with pre-existing conditions, Trumpcare spends $29 on tax breaks for the wealthy.   The truth is if my Republican colleagues really want to address health care reform, we need to work together to improve the Affordable Care Act insurance exchanges, not blow them up. There are common sense actions we can take to improve them, but we won’t improve the exchanges by cut slashing Medicaid by $834 billion and cutting tax credits that make care more affordable. These reckless actions will take away lifesaving health coverage from millions and raise the cost of health care—not only for those who receive coverage through the Affordable Care Act exchanges. It’s time to throw out Trumpcare 2.0 and focus on improving the ACA Insurance Exchanges.

As a chess player (though not a very good one) myself, I loved reading this story about Cahree Myrick, a dedicated and talented seventh grader from Baltimore. Congratulations to Cahree who had a perfect 7-0 score at the national chess tournament. You make Maryland proud!

President Trump’s devastating decision to withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement threatens U.S. jobs, our economic competitiveness, and the health of our planet. By rejecting the scientific consensus that has brought nearly 200 nations together to address the immediate threat of climate change, President Trump is ceding America's leadership in building a 21st century clean energy economy—and the jobs that go with it—to countries like China.   The President is also abdicating responsibility to protect communities in Maryland and across the country from the costly threats of drought, wildfire, storms, and sea level rise. Coming on the heels of an overseas trip in which our allies questioned America's reliability, this decision further isolates the United States on the world stage and undermines American strength. On President Trump’s recent trip to Rome, the Pope gifted him a copy of his encyclical on the moral imperative to act on climate change – the President should have read it before making this ignorant and destructive decision that will affect generations to come.

I #WearOrange because the level of gun violence in our neighborhoods and communities is a national disgrace. While we stand in solidarity today with families across the country who've had to confront with the unimaginable reality of losing a loved one to gun violence, we must fight back against powerful special interests —like the NRA —that are standing in the way of proven, policies to reduce gun violence in our country. Proud to be in the fight for common sense gun reform—the time for action is long past due.

The Trump administration's proposals to cut thousands of positions at the State Department and USAID and eliminate missions worldwide would undermine America’s ability to influence events abroad and tackle the enormous challenges presented by countries suffering from the root causes of so many conflicts we see today—poor governance, extreme poverty and rampant corruption.  Last week I was proud to join with my fellow co-chair of the Senate Foreign Service Caucus and Republican colleague Senator Dan Sullivan to express our concerns to Secretary Tillerson about the impact these cuts would have on our national security. We cannot afford to erode America’s leadership in the world and our ability to confront these and other global challenges. Our embassies, consulates, and USAID missions, often working hand-in-hand with the Department of Defense, can play a critical role in helping to prevent violence from escalating and assisting countries seeking to transition from conflict to stability. A world where America is in retreat, where Americans and American diplomats are not at the table, is not a world that will be able to advance our common values, strengthen democracy and undermine the forces of extremism.

Back in November, the Trump Administration promised the American people that there would be no tax cuts for the upper class. Yet, the analysis of the Trumpcare tax cuts clearly shows that millionaires will get, on average, $50,000 a year in tax cuts. Republicans are leaving 23 million people without health care coverage, leaving individuals with pre-existing conditions skyrocketing premiums, and gutting Medicaid by $834 billion just so they can cut taxes by hundreds of billions of dollars for wealthy households and insurance companies. In fact, for every $1 allocated to cover people with pre-existing conditions, Trumpcare spends $29 on tax breaks for the wealthy—totally violating the standard they set forward in November. It’s rotten to the core, and any small tweaks that Senator McConnell and Republican Senators are considering won’t change that fact. We must prevent this warped Wealthcare proposal from passing the U.S. Senate in any form.    Tune in as I join Senator Ron Wyden, Senator Chris Murphy, and Senator Edward J. Markey to highlight the immoral tax provisions in Trumpcare.

As the Trumpcare proposal threatens access to affordable health care for those with pre-existing conditions and people with disabilities, we need to fight back to make sure every American has the care they need. The first step is to speak out against President Trump’s “alternative facts” about his horrendous Wealthcare proposal, which would strip a whopping $834 billion from Medicaid while shoveling out hundreds of billions of tax cuts to wealthy households and powerful special interests. We must listen to and share stories about how Trumpcare will do grave harm to our fellow Americans. Tune in and share this live stream from U.S. Senator Bob Casey to hold President Trump accountable and make sure he doesn’t violate the promises he made to keep Medicaid intact. With your help, we can make sure Trumpcare 2.0 doesn’t pass the Senate.

Today I participated in a rally where we heard from Americans who would be personally harmed by Trumpcare, including many of my constituents. I want to share with you something that I received at the rally from my constituent, Ken Capone, about how critical Medicaid has been to him and his family. Ken wrote:  “I, along with millions of people with disabilities, have proven the doctors wrong! We can be employed, we can have relationships and families, we can own a house, we can live in the community, we can live the lives we want to live.  None of this would be possible if I did not have Medicaid funding to pay for the staff I need to help me with all my daily living activities. It’s scary to think what my life would look like if Medicaid was cut or a cap to states. Will I have to pick what services I need the most, or even worse, would I have to go into a state residential center or a nursing facility to get the essential daily living supports that I need?”   Like many people with disabilities who were born 40 or 50 years ago, the doctors told Ken’s parents to put him in an institution because he wouldn’t be able to function in society.  But, with the help of Medicaid, he and his parents were able to benefit from services that he needed not just to survive, but to live the life he wants to live.  We must not return to the days when living with a disability meant you had to live in a segregated institution. We must continue to build an inclusive society where all Americans can thrive and lead independent and fulfilling lives.

There is no excuse for inaction. The United States must show Putin that we will not stand idly by while he attacks our democracy. We need to be unified in our resolve and put patriotism over partisanship. That’s why shortly after the Comey hearings today, I went down to the Senate floor to speak about how Congress must pass sanctions on Russia.

So you can imagine my surprise when the Trump Administration budget proposed to completely eliminate funding for the federal program that was used to launch the Center visited by Ivanka Trump. Well said, Senator Claire McCaskill. My Democratic colleagues and I have said time and again that we would work with Republicans to improve the Affordable Care Act, but they refuse to work with us. Instead, they’ve decided to hide behind closed doors without anyone else's input. It’s time for Senate Republicans to show us their plan and work with us on ways to improve our health care system—not rip it apart.

The United States expelled Russian spies from diplomatic compounds—like the one in Eastern Maryland—because of Russia’s interference in our elections. It is outrageous that President Trump would reward Russia by allowing their officials to return to these properties, instead of sanctioning them for engaging in political cyber warfare during our elections—especially as Russia flagrantly meddles in other elections around the world. This just gives Putin the green light to continue attacking democracy here and elsewhere.    There’s no excuse for inaction. That’s why I support bipartisan legislation to impose additional sanctions on Putin and have filed two amendments to ensure that we have a long-term approach to combat Russia’s cyber warfare. The amendments shore up our own cyber defenses in advance of our next elections and prevent the President from rewarding Putin by returning the compounds in Maryland and New York. The stakes are too high. Congress must pass Russia sanctions now.

Why are Senate Republicans drafting their health care bill in secret? They are clearly afraid the American people will hate what they see.  In 2009, the Senate spent 25 days publicly debating the details of the Affordable Care Act before passing the bill. But Senate Republican efforts to draft a Trumpcare 2.0 bill have been shrouded in unprecedented secrecy. They have been meeting behind closed doors and in private lunch, groups to haggle over a new health care bill. Then they plan to rush their legislation straight to the Senate floor for a vote before the July 4th with no opportunity for Democrats, or the public, to review the details in Committee hearings or markup—and without even releasing the text of the updated health care bill until the last possible minute.  Americans' health care is too important to ram it through the Senate under cover of darkness. Every citizen should demand an end to the secret meetings and ask Republicans senators why they are hiding their work from their constituents.

President Trump has a troubling pattern of trying to fire anyone who disagrees with him or doesn’t pledge their unconditional loyalty. Yesterday, it was reported that Trump is considering firing the special counsel, former FBI Director Robert Mueller, who was appointed by Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein to investigate the Trump Administration's ties to Russia. Many of the Trump allies who once praised Mr. Mueller are now trying to undermine his credibility. At this time, Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein is the only person who can fire Special Counsel Mueller and this morning I had the opportunity to question him about that authority. The good news is that Rosenstein pledged that he would not remove Mueller without "good cause" and agreed that an order from the President did not constitute "good cause." But I am very concerned that Trump could fire Rosenstein and anyone else until he found someone willing to do the dirty deed. We need to build the case that Mueller could refuse to accept any wrongful firing that was done without good cause.

Since the ratification of our Constitution, one of the most critical protections against corruption and undue foreign influence in our national decision-making has been the Emoluments Clause. The Emoluments Clause forbids the President from accepting gifts, payments or benefits from foreign states without congressional approval. No American should have to wonder whether the president of the United States is putting his personal financial interests ahead of our country’s best interests.   President Trump has refused to take measures to comply with this critical Constitutional requirement. He could put his business holdings into a blind trust—but he has refused. He could provide the transparency of releasing his tax returns, as the Presidents have done for the last 40 years—again, he refused. As long as Mr. Trump continues to accept benefits from foreign governments and leave this Administration exposed to this potentially corrupting influence, Congress has no choice but to ask the courts to intervene.   That’s why I’m joining Senator Richard Blumenthal, Congressman John Conyers, Jr., and 169 other Members of Congress to ask the courts to compel President Trump to comply. No person is above the Constitution—not even the President. This is about making sure the President is looking out for the American people’s interests, not using the White House to expand his own personal wealth.

Today is the annual Congressional Baseball Game, a tradition that brings Democrats and Republicans together to pick up a mitt to play one of our nation’s favorite pastimes and raise money for a local charity. Yesterday’s horrific attack on Republican members and staff as they practiced for this game underscores the need to remember what unites our Congressional community, not just what divides it.  While we have significant differences on how to address many of the challenges and opportunities our country faces, we are united by our faith in our democratic system and the belief that violence has no place in our political process. Today’s game sends a clear, unified message that those who seek to disrupt and divide our country through violence will not succeed. On that important issue, we stand united.

It’s disgraceful that President Trump hasn’t taken any actions against Russia for its interference in our elections, and is instead still considering returning diplomatic compounds in Maryland and New York that Russia used to spy on us.   Vladimir Putin has not come clean on his aggressive intervention into our elections last year. Nor has he or his government provided any assurances that these attacks will not happen again. That’s why yesterday the US Senate took bipartisan action to demonstrate that we will not stand idly by when our democracy is under attack. We passed tough sanctions against Russia and sent a unified and unequivocal message to Putin that we cannot have improved relations until they stop interfering in our democracy and those of our allies. These sanctions also incorporate my amendment to prevent President Trump from allowing Russians access to the diplomatic compounds like the one of the Eastern Shore without the consent of Congress. As I discussed with Secretary of State Tillerson earlier this week in the Senate Appropriations Committee—we need to be clear and unequivocal in sending a strong message to the Kremlin about protecting our democracy from intervention. I commend my colleagues for working across the aisle on this critical issue.

President Trump’s announcement that he will tighten restrictions on economic and cultural engagement between the United States and Cuba is a wrongheaded move that only benefits those in the Cuban regime who rely on an adversarial relationship with America to justify political repression. Expanded commercial opportunities with Cuba have benefited U.S. farmers, agricultural workers, businesses, and exporters and helped bring new resources and ideas directly to the Cuban people.  Two years ago I had the honor of playing a small role in helping our country open a new relationship with Cuba when President Obama invited me to fly to Havana to bring home my constituent Alan Gross, who had been imprisoned there for nearly five years. Alan did not ask to shape history. He was unjustly swept up in the conflict between the U.S. and Cuba. But, in the end, Alan proved to be a catalyst for change. Alan was not only thrilled to be free but also openly welcomed the Obama Administration's approach to Cuba and its people. Since that time, the slow, but steady progress that has taken place in our relationship has helped both Americans and the Cuban people. President Trump’s new policy turns back the clock, slows the progress toward greater openness and brings back old rhetoric associated with the same policy of isolationism that failed for five decades. If our President cared more about creating American jobs and helping Cuba open up its society, than he did about satisfying a few of his hardline political supporters, he would embrace more engagement with the Cuban people—not less.

Under the cover of darkness, Senate Republicans continue to write a health care bill in secrecy. This is not the way the Senate should work. Normally, the Senate would hold hearings—with experts, doctors, patients, and stakeholders – in full view of the American public. A bill would be worked up through committees and senators would have the opportunity to review the bill and suggest changes.  The Republicans are hiding their health care bill because they know that the more people learn about how the Senate version of Trumpcare would raise their health care costs, gut Medicaid, and throw tens of millions of people off of health care—the more they’ll hold Republicans accountable.

Watch live as I join  U.S. Senator Bob Casey, U.S. Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, and Senator Maggie Hassan to detail how the Republicans' health care plan will impact millions of older Americans across the country.

This morning I met with Marylanders who are terrified that their lives and livelihoods could be put at risk by the Republican health care plan. Even President Trump behind closed doors last week said the bill that passed the House is plain “mean.”  It’s mean to tens of millions of Americans, including millions of Marylanders. People like Molly from Baltimore, whose cancer would have gone undetected without the Affordable Care Act, and Katie from Westminster whose two-year-old daughter’s life would literally be on the line if Medicaid is cut.   It’s time for Republican senators to come out of the dark to show us the bill. We need everybody in America to continue speaking out: Share your story using the hashtag #AmericaSpeaksOut. I pledge I will do everything in my power to stop this unconscionable attack on America’s healthcare from taking effect.

While Senate Republicans continue to craft a health care bill behind closed doors, I had the opportunity to debate with one of my Republican colleagues—Senator John Barrasso—on pieces of their secretive bill. Debate amongst opposing parties and open dialogue is what our democratic process is all about. But, it’s a real shame we only have a chance to debate the merits of the health bill with GOP senators on TV with no opportunity to provide input and amendments on behalf of the public in Committee. #ShowUsTheBill

Make no mistake—in many ways the Republican Senate's "health" plan is much worse and meaner than the House bill. That is especially true with respect to its deeper long-term cuts to Medicaid, which helps provide affordable care to seniors, individuals with disabilities, and lower-income families. The Republican Senate bill will do grave harm to children like Allison’s son Julian and other children with disabilities. Making health care unaffordable for millions of Americans like Julian and his family is, simply, wrong. In Maryland alone, this proposal would harm 2.6 million seniors, disabled persons, and lower income people.   How can Republican Senators defend a reckless plan like this at the same time they are pushing for tax breaks for the wealthiest in our country? We need to stand up for what’s right and fight this latest Trumpcare abomination. We need to stay focused on the bottom line—how these proposals will affect families like Allison’s and tens of millions of others who will lose a vital lifeline to affordable care. Let’s continue to make our voices heard and fight like hell. #AmericaSpeaksOut

The Republican bill that was released today isn’t a health care bill, it’s a massive transfer of wealth from middle-class and poor families to the richest people in America. I’ll fight this in the Senate, but I’ll need your reinforcement: We need everybody across Maryland and the country to share their stories about how this immoral monstrosity will impact their lives. We’ve got to stop it and I will fight tooth and nail, but we don’t have a lot of time since Republicans are trying to push it through before the end of next week. Let’s get to work.

With help from some of my staff in our Rockville office, he and his sister were able to come to the U.S. and reunite with their family. Selama has a bright future ahead of him.

The Forum will be held Saturday from 2:30 to 4:30 pm at Mt. Nebo AME Church, 1001 Old Mitchellville Rd in Bowie, Maryland. The Senate Republicans have said they will try to ram their plan through the Senate in the coming week. At this Forum we will discuss actions we can take together to stop them from passing this moral monstrosity.

I’m in Bowie today to talk with Marylanders and health care professionals from across the state about the moral imperative to provide quality, affordable health care to all Americans and the devastating impact that the Senate Republicans’ plan would have on our community and country.  I will fight this proposal tooth and nail in the Senate, but my colleagues and I will need reinforcement from Americans across the country. Thank you to the more than 500 Marylanders and who came out to our Health Care Forum in Bowie yesterday.  This coming week Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell will try to ram the atrocious GOP Wealthcare bill through the Senate. I will fight it tooth and nail—but we need reinforcements from Americans across the country. Everyone in every state needs to let their senators know they will not stand for this assault on our health care. It’s up to all of us to stand up and speak out.

I just finished reviewing the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) report about the Senate Republicans’ "health care" bill. Right now I’m headed to the Senate Floor to talk about why this unconscionable bill—TrumpCare 3.0—is rotten to the core and more bad news for American families. Tune in and don’t forget to share with your friends and family across the country—affordable, quality health care is too important to stand idly by.

One of the thousands of constituents I've heard from is Katie from Westminster, who has a 2-year-old daughter who needs constant monitoring and care for her bone marrow and heart diseases. For Katie, maintaining access to affordable health care is a matter of life or death for her daughter, and she's worried about what the future holds.  With this new Republican plan that's being rushed through the Senate, her daughter's health care would be in jeopardy if Katie were to change jobs. As a hardworking mom who is already struggling financially, juggling expenses for medicines, co-pays, and transportation to medical appointments for her daughter, it doesn't make any sense to ask people like Katie to pay more, while giving a tax break to the powerful special interests and the top 1% wealthiest households.  I stand ready to discuss ideas to improve our health care system—as long as the common goal is to increase access and affordability of care for Marylanders. But the plan Senate Republicans put forward fails that basic test. More people need to hear stories like Katie's, and I stand with her and every Marylander who wants to improve our health care system—not destroy it.

America's great philosopher, Yogi Berra, had it right when he said, “It ain’t over till it’s over.” We had some preliminary good news today—Mitch McConnell delayed the vote on Senate Republicans’ WealthCare bill. But that doesn’t mean it’s time for a victory lap—now is the time to redouble our efforts to stop this unconscionable bill. Your voices are already being heard, so when Republican Senators go back to their home states during the July 4 recess, we must make sure they hear from their constituents in their home states. We won’t stand for any bill that strips health care away from tens of millions of Americans!

I want to thank everyone who came to the opening of our new Baltimore Regional Office last night. Our offices throughout the state are there for people in communities across Maryland to come to address any constituent issues they make have, whether it involves help with Social Security, veterans care, Medicare coverage, or any other matter. No Marylander’s issue or concern is too small—and if it’s a matter we can't solve by ourselves, we will reach out to other partners wherever they may be—in the non-profit or private sector, as well as those at all levels of government: federal, state and local. Even when the Congress seems to be gridlocked, our work in the community continues. My team and I will always be there to listen and assist.

Looking forward to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator's response as to why he took down factual evidence—hailed as the gold standard from both Democrats and Republicans alike—about climate change from the EPA’s website.

Carroll County’s 19-year-old Jarrett Justice is realizing his long-held dream of service to our country in the military as he prepares to attend West Point this fall. To Jarrett and all the other young Marylanders preparing to launch into new endeavors after high school—you represent the future of our state and country.  Work hard, stay true to your values, reach for your dreams.

Today’s CBO analysis shows that, when it comes to Medicaid cuts, the Senate Republicans’ “WealthCare” bill is even meaner than it looks—and the more time goes by, the meaner it gets. The Senate plan is deceptively structured to try to hide this effect in the traditional CBO analysis, but today's CBO assessment shows how these cuts will become even more devastating over time. The original analysis shows that Medicaid would be cut by  a whopping 25 percent over ten years. This update shows it is headed in a downward death spiral—falling to 35 percent over two decades and plummeting further as time goes on. Seniors in nursing homes, millions of children, people with disabilities, and struggling working families will suffer terrible harm in order to give tax cuts to the rich. That is simply immoral. Any Republican Senators who were already concerned about the magnitude of the Medicaid cuts should read this CBO analysis and firmly reject any bill that goes in this direction.

Very confused because Ben Carson—the Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD)—is saying one thing in Baltimore but doing the opposite in Washington, D.C. He says he wants to expand public-private partnerships in Baltimore through programs like the Rental Assistance Demonstration (RAD), which helps fund public housing projects and repairs. While I support these partnerships, on Capitol Hill Secretary Carson is proposing a budget that will undermine this effort. The budget that he and President Trump have proposed would cut HUD’s programs by $7.5 billion, including reductions for public housing and vouchers that help families pay for rent. Those massive cuts would sabotage the Rental Assistance Demonstration project. I  would like to work with Secretary Carson on this effort in Baltimore but it will be hard to expand these private-public partnerships with massive cuts to public housing funds. Let's avoid these cuts and work together to expand access to more affordable housing.

If we’re going to have a strong economy in Maryland, it’s essential that we have a clean and healthy Bay. It is vital to our tourism industry, to our watermen, and to our boating industry—and that’s why decades ago Maryland, Virginia, Delaware, West Virginia, Pennsylvania, New York, and the District of Columbia forged a compact with the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to help protect our coastal economies and the environment. And during EPA Administrator Pruitt’s confirmation hearing, he promised Senator Ben Cardin and all of us who care about the Bay that he’d uphold that commitment. But, totally eliminating the Chesapeake Bay Program—vital federal funds that help us continue cleaning up the Bay—from the Trump Administration’s budget does not help us meet that commitment. It is totally dishonest to say you’ll work with us to protect the Bay, but then eliminate funding for programs that support it. I will continue to put pressure on Administrator Pruitt—as I know my colleagues will as well—to ensure we have the funding we need to protect our coastal economy and the Bay ecosystems.
I love the 4th of July! It was great to join Marylanders of all backgrounds and political stripes to celebrate  our love of country and the right to freely express our views. Happy 4th to all!

Last week the Maryland Congressional Delegation had a hearing on Capitol Hill to discuss the progress of the Chesapeake Bay clean-up effort. The testimony from Will Baker, the President of the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, Brian Grumbles, the Secretary of the Maryland Department of the Environment and Stephen Abel, the Executive Director of the Oyster Recovery Partnership was upbeat about the progress we have made, but they all emphasized the vital role the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has played since the 1980s in cleaning up the Bay.  The Trump Administration's proposal to eliminate EPA's funding for the Bay would put the progress we have made at risk. That is why I am pleased by the bipartisan opposition in the Congress to the Trump proposal. The Washington Post story below shows why EPA's involvement is so important. More than half of the fresh water in the Bay comes down the Susquehanna River from Pennsylvania, and our witnesses last week estimated that about as much pollution comes into the Bay from the Susquehanna as from all other sources combined. EPA's involvement will be essential to securing the cooperation of officials and stakeholders there. I have already discussed this matter with members of the Pennsylvania congressional delegation, but without the EPA, we have little leverage. The Chesapeake Bay clean up is a success story to date, but its future health depends on a strong role for the EPA. Let's make sure we don't blow it.

Since May, the Trump Administration has been pursuing the President’s baseless and widely discredited claims that he won the popular vote amid  “widespread voter fraud." It's outrageous that President Trump is wasting taxpayer dollars as part of this charade, but has failed to fully acknowledge that the Russian government organized hackers to launch cyber-attacks on our state and local electoral systems—something that has been unanimously recognized by all the American Intelligence agencies.    What’s even more troubling is that President Trump’s “Commission on Election Integrity” has now called on states to provide sensitive voter information and data, including names, addresses, dates of birth, political parties, voter histories, and the last four digits of millions of Americans' social security numbers. That’s why Senator Amy Klobuchar and I sent a letter to the Commission’s chairman Vice President Pence and vice-chairman Kansas’ Secretary of State Chris Kobach requesting further information about how the Commission intends to use and protect this data. At a time when cybersecurity should be a top priority, it’s critical that we raise these serious privacy and safety concerns.   Maryland, along with 43 other states, share our concern, including Republican officials from Mississippi, Tennessee, and Ohio. What’s astounding is even vice-chair Kobach, has indicated that officials from his own state of Kansas will not fully comply with the Commission’s request. Instead of demanding that states hand over sensitive personal information, President Trump should hold Vladimir Putin accountable for attacking our democratic process. He can start by confronting Putin about this issue when they meet tomorrow and make it clear that he will support the Russia sanctions legislation that recently passed the Senate with an overwhelming bipartisan vote.  We should be putting country before politics.

This week I traveled to Beacon of Hope Recovery Center in St. Mary’s County to talk with health care professionals, law enforcement, and those in recovery about how important it is to treat addiction like a health issue, not a criminal justice issue. Sadly, while we’re working to do whatever necessary to combat a horrific opioid epidemic in Maryland and across the country, Senate Republicans’ “WealthCare” proposal will drastically cut Medicaid, and ultimately take away critical funding that these types of recovery centers rely on to give their patients the treatment they need. Now is the time to do what is necessary to ensure facilities like this one have the funding they need to help folks get their lives back on track to become full, productive members of society.

Next week Senators will return to Washington D.C. and the Republican Leader, Mitch McConnell, will continue to pressure his Republican colleagues to pass some version of their unconscionable WealthCare bill. The only people who can stop them are their own constituents. That is why U.S. Senate Democrats want to make sure the American people are weighing in on this important issue at this crucial moment. Take the time to watch our Democratic Weekly Address and hear about why the Senate Republican health care bill would be devastating to millions of Americans. And after you’re done, ask your friends and family in states across the country to reach out to Senators in the critical states to share their views and their stories.

Today the Trump Administration has pulled the plug on the decades-long search for a new FBI headquarters. This decision comes even after Congress has spoken very clearly on multiple occasions that it intends to fully fund the consolidated FBI project. Canceling the current request for proposals puts America’s national security at risk. The Hoover Building—the D.C. location of the current Headquarters—is crumbling around the FBI, and it’s simply reckless for the Trump Administration to blow up the ongoing process of securing a location for the FBI workforce that serves on the front lines of our nation’s law enforcement and counter terrorism efforts.  Not only has the federal government made a massive investment, but the State of Maryland and Prince George’s County have invested immense resources and time into this project. But for the Trump Administration—after failing to include any funding in the President’s budget proposal—to scrap this project entirely before the budget process is even halfway complete, is a waste of hundreds of millions of federal, state, and local taxpayer dollars.  Our national security mandates that we move forward with building a secure, fully consolidated FBI headquarters. I—along with the Maryland Delegation—strongly disagree with this decision. If the Trump Administration is unwilling to reconsider their position, then GSA should move forward as quickly as possible by selecting one of the other various financing mechanisms identified and thoroughly examined by GSA. Team Maryland, including our federal delegation, state and local officials, will continue to work together to ensure the fully consolidated FBI headquarters project comes to fruition.

Last night I was on the Senate Floor to talk about how the Senate Republicans’ health care bill is rotten to its core—and how a little deodorant will not make it any better. In Maryland alone, over 22,000 people would lose coverage under this proposal and average premiums would increase by $1,035 in 2018 – that’s just next year. And it just gets worse over time: In 2020, 60-year-olds in Maryland earning $45,000 annually could pay as much as $8,860 more a year in premiums.   I’m grateful for the thousands of calls and emails I’ve received that oppose this immoral WealthCare bill, but we must continue to speak out. Now is not the time to slow down—the next three weeks will determine the fate of our health care system. Will we let Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Senate Republicans’ turn back the clock and raise health insurance premiums just to give the very wealthy and special interests a windfall tax break? Or will we continue to fight back tooth and nail to stop this unconscionable bill so we can move forward to improve our current system? It’s up to all of us, so tune as we continue the fight in the Senate.

Today the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) proved what we’ve suspected all along: President Trump’s budget balances only if you ignore basic math and believe in fraudulent accounting. But the real problem with his budget is that it betrays his campaign promises to create an economy that helps working families, to protect vulnerable Americans, and to strengthen rural America. Marylanders would be harmed by his proposal to slash investments to modernize our infrastructure, to boost medical research, and to protect the Chesapeake Bay. President Trump claims this budget puts ‘America First’—but the only winners I see are the very wealthy and powerful special interests, not the hard working Americans he promised to fight for.

Yesterday I met my constituent Rick Werner and his family, who have had to endure the deep pain of losing a child to an opioid overdose. Rick told me about his son Jamie, who was a proud University of Maryland Terp, special education teacher, and an amazing cook with a kind heart.   I am tremendously grateful to my constituents, like Rick and his family, who selflessly share their stories so that millions of other Americans can have the lifesaving health care they need. The pain associated with losing a child to substance abuse is one that no parent should ever have to endure, and make no mistake—it takes tremendous courage, grit, resolve, and strength to speak out.   At the end of the day, these are the stories that people need to hear as we are fighting the Senate Republicans’ health care bill. I believe, with all of my heart, that these personal stories will save lives and give millions of others the strength they need to continue fighting this immoral bill.

With Kim Jong Un now capable of launching an intercontinental ballistic missile that could reach Alaska, the United States needs to exert maximum pressure on North Korea and its enablers to end its nuclear weapons program. North Korea has crossed a critical and dangerous threshold, and the United States must take action. That’s why earlier this week Senator Pat Toomey and I introduced bipartisan legislation that will fill an important gap in our current sanctions regime against North Korea by going after the foreign banks and firms that have provided illicit support to Kim Jong Un. It will send a clear and unequivocal message: The economic consequences will be severe for those who continue to do business with North Korea. Our goal is to achieve a Korean Peninsula free of nuclear weapons.

Earlier this month, I had the privilege of meeting one my constituents, Susan Flashman and her husband Richard from Mount Rainier. Susan is a 63-year-old retired union electrician, dog rescuer and all-around animal lover who was willing to speak out to help protect affordable health care for our fellow Americans. Back in 2011, doctors discovered a cyst in Susan’s brain that developed into a tumor. In order to save her life, she had to undergo surgery. It took about a year of rehabilitation for Susan to be somewhat functional, but sadly, because of permanent damage that affected her balance, she was left unable to work again.  But the fight didn’t end there for Susan—she had to continue carrying the burden of the steep medical costs associated with her surgery and rehabilitation. The hospital bills alone were over $100,000. But fortunately, she was able to receive the critical care she needed because she was covered under the Affordable Care Act’s employer-based insurance market protections.  For Susan and hundreds of thousands like her with a pre-existing condition, the new Senate Republican health care bill is even worse than the first one. The provision added by Senator Ted Cruz allows insurance companies to segregate the market into those who feel they are invincible (they can purchase cheaper "junk insurance" plans only to discover their insurance doesn't cover their unexpected needs) and those who expect to need decent coverage. Individuals like Susan with any kind of pre-existing conditions will see huge, unaffordable price spikes. Even insurance companies concede the Cruz amendment will throw much of the insurance market into a death spiral.   We must stop this assault on common decency. I’m grateful to Susan and all the others who’ve shared their personal stories to protect our fellow Americans. We must start working together to improve our current health care system instead of totally blowing it up. Together, we will make sure affordable health care isn’t a privilege reserved for a few but a fundamental right for all.

I wish Senator John McCain a full and swift recovery. Now that Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell is postponing the vote on the so-called heath care bill, why not use the extra time to have public hearings to listen to the American people. Instead of trying to make pork-barrel back room deals—like the Kodiak Kickback for Alaska—to entice wavering Senate Republican to vote for this unconscionable bill, Senator McConnell should use this additional time to hold public hearings to listen to individuals who will be impacted by the bill. If McConnell is proud of this proposal, why not invite public testimony from health care advocates, doctors, nurses and patient advocacy groups? Why not hear from impartial experts about the impact of the Ted Cruz amendment to segregate the insurance market? The answer is that he doesn't want the American people to hear the truth because the more they know, the more they hate the plan. Please join me in calling upon Senator McConnell to stop the back room deals to deny affordable care to millions of Americans and, instead, open the hearing rooms to testimony from the American public. Don't be so afraid of the truth!

There is no question that secret outside spending is having a dramatic—and detrimental—impact on our nation’s democracy. Tune in as I speak about how we can limit the influence of dark money in our politics and increase transparency.

President Trump and Senate Republicans are running in circles when it comes to pushing their rotten health care plans, which get meaner by the day. Just yesterday, President Trump and Senator McConnell called upon Senate Republicans to immediately repeal and then later replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA).  They clearly need to read today's nonpartisan analysis from the Congressional Budget Office (CBO), which says that plan would cause premiums to double and 32 million more Americans to be uninsured by 2026.  After the emergency meeting today between President Trump and Senate Republicans, McConnell announced that he will hold a vote next week to consider one or all of the rotten proposals that have been put forward to date—including immediate repeal. This is totally out of control and no way to treat the health care of our fellow Americans. It is time for President Trump and Senate Republicans to stop trying to destroy the ACA and start working with Democrats to strengthen our health care system for all Americans.    This battle is still not over. The Senate Republican leadership will try every trick in the book to pull a fast one. We need you to stay in the fight. Share your stories and keep reaching out to your friends and relatives around the country. We cannot go backwards. We need to move forward and ensure quality, affordable health care for all Americans.

Frederick Douglass was a great American hero and Marylander. Enslaved at birth in Talbot County, he grew to become a national leader in the fight to end slavery and gain the right to vote for women. In his 20’s Douglass escaped slavery and eventually fled to England. In 1846 British Quakers raised funds to pay for his freedom and he returned home to the United States. He became one of the greatest orators, writers and social reformers in American history. His autobiography, "Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave," was a bestseller during his lifetime and Frederick Douglass played a central role in the abolitionist movement and became a world renowned leader in the fight to end the evil institution of slavery.    I’m proud to introduce the Frederick Douglass Bicentennial Commission Act in the Senate as a companion bill to legislation introduced in the House of Representatives by House of Representatives by Congresswoman Eleanor Holmes Norton and Congressman Andy Harris. This legislation would establish a commission to honor and celebrate Frederick Douglass in 2018 as we mark the 200th anniversary of his birth—and will explore how we can celebrate his legacy and redouble our efforts to build an ever more perfect union.
Happy Birthday to an incredible friend, role model and one of the fiercest fighters I know. When Barbara Mikulski is with you, the Force is with you!

A few weeks ago I had the opportunity to sit down around a table for coffee with agricultural leaders and farmers in Calvert County to hear what’s on their minds. We shared ideas about how Congress can support one of our fast-growing economic engines—Maryland agriculture.  Yesterday I had the chance to put some of their ideas to work when the Senate Appropriations Committee met to vote on the budget for agriculture and conservation programs. I am pleased that—on a bipartisan basis—we unanimously rejected many of the very deep cuts that the President's budget had proposed to make in rural areas. The Committee strongly supported investments that are important to farmers and help protect the Chesapeake Bay, like the Conservation Technical Assistance (CTA) program. Through CTA, the Natural Resource Conservation Service (NRCS) field staff work one-on-one with farmers in Maryland and other states to develop and implement conservation plans that address how farmers can best conserve resources on their farms. I am also pleased that the Committee supported strong funding for the Agricultural Research Service (ARS)—which is headquartered in Beltsville and has facilities in Frederick. Their work provides essential support that helps farmers and consumers alike.  I am also thrilled to report that every member of the Committee—Democrat and Republican alike—voted to restore key rural development funding for the Rural Water and Waste Disposal Program and important rural energy programs—projects that the Trump Administration had proposed to eliminate entirely.    In addition to the Appropriations Committee, I am proud to be the first Maryland senator in nearly 100 years to serve on the Agriculture Committee.
