I look forward to continuing to work with our farmers and agricultural leaders in all parts of our state to bring good ideas and common sense to Capitol Hill.

After all the rallies, phone calls, and town halls, the battle over the future direction of our health care system is likely to come down to what happens in the coming week. Senate Republican Leader McConnell is pleading with his Republican Caucus to allow us to move forward on a bill—he just can't tell them what that health care bill will be. It could be the proposal to wipe out the Affordable Care Act (ACA)—even though the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) just informed us that would cause premiums to double and 32 million Americans would lose access to affordable care. Or, it could be the latest version of their plan to "replace" the ACA. Yesterday, the CBO told us that plan was just as bad as the earlier version. In fact, it is worse because it contains Senator Cruz’s amendment that will provide junk insurance for some and skyrocketing, unaffordable costs for others, especially those with pre-existing conditions.  All of these plans are rotten to the core. All of them have the same DNA—they strip away affordable care from many in order to give tax breaks to a powerful few. So we cannot let our guard down until we defeat and bury them. We are fighting for mothers like Angela, April, and countless others who stay awake at night worrying about how they’ll care for their children or loved ones without access to affordable health care. This is a fight we cannot afford to lose!   So if you have a friend, family member, or if you have your own personal story you’d be willing to tell—please share them with me in the comments below. I am convinced that your stories—and those that have come in from around the country—have stopped these unconscionable plans so far. Let's win this battle so we can then focus on improving our health care system and ensuring quality, affordable health care for all. Are you in?

Inspiring meeting with young Marylanders from Girl Up this week, a United Nations Foundation campaign that advocates for the rights of young women around the globe. At a time when we have an Administration that is pushing for severe cuts to foreign assistance—including to health and education for women and girls—the efforts of Girl Up are more important than ever. Thanks to Girl Up’s passionate advocates for standing up, speaking out, and supporting girls worldwide!

Earlier this month I had the privilege of meeting one my younger constituents, six-year-old Timmy, his sister Ivy, and his parents Mark and Michelle from Laurel. Timmy is a newly minted kindergarten graduate who loves robots and pirates, plays on a local soccer team, and dreams of growing up to become a police officer, firefighter, “ambulance man,” garbage collector, or robot repairman. He is exuberant, hilarious, creative, and one of the most resilient children you will ever meet.   Timmy was born—just six days after the initial provision of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) kicked in—with a rare condition that requires him to breathe through a tube in his throat. But with quality, affordable healthcare that blocks lifetime maximums, Timmy lives a fairly normal life for a kindergartener and is able to avoid lengthy in-patient hospital stays.   If Senate Republicans implement their WealthCare plan or repeal the ACA—it would be devastating for both Timmy’s health and his family’s finances. We must keep fighting for all the little kids, seniors, and Americans whose lives would be put at risk simply because President Trump is pressuring Senate Republicans to use the health care of millions as a political pawn. Watch and share Timmy’s story below.

Too many Marylanders and folks across the country are working harder than ever but not getting ahead. Too many feel like they’re on a treadmill going nowhere or falling further behind. They are being squeezed between flat or shrinking paychecks, on the one hand, and rising costs on the other. And it is not enough to simply analyze or empathize with these challenges—we must have a plan to do something about it. That’s why today, House Democrats and U.S. Senate Democrats are laying out an economic plan that will give Americans #ABetterDeal. The plan includes specific ways to promote good paying jobs and reduce the skyrocketing cost of prescription drugs, child care and other goods and services. It is vital that we continue to fight President Trump's efforts to turn back the clock on progress in America. But it is not enough that people know what we are fighting against; they must also know what we are fighting for. We are for a Better Deal for America. Watch ↓ and share: democrats.senate.gov/abetterdeal.

Senator Ben Cardin and I have been reaching out to local and state officials to let them know we stand ready to provide any assistance we can to the people of Stevensville on Kent Island as they recover from last night’s storm and possible tornado. We appreciate the speed and skill of the first responders and all those working to return the community to a sense of normalcy in the aftermath of such sudden destruction. We have been in contact with local authorities to offer support and any guidance as they begin damage assessments. If state officials deem it appropriate, we will lead Team Maryland to express our strong support for a federal disaster declaration to make federal funding available for emergency work and the repair or replacement of facilities damaged by the storm. If you need assistance or want to help those impacted, follow Maryland Emergency Management Agency (MEMA) and visit www.qac.org for updates.

Today I’m speaking with Ola Ojewumi, one of my constituents from Beltsville. When Ola was just 11 years old, she received a rare heart and kidney transplant. Like most kids in the fifth grade, Ola was preparing for her yearly physical and expected to receive a clean bill of health. But in less than two minutes, the diagnosis of a rare heart condition changed her life forever, and she was told she’d require lifelong medical care.   Sadly, Ola’s health struggles didn’t stop there: Just last year, Ola was diagnosed with lymphoma, a post-transplant cancer, and received treatment at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Maryland. But thanks to the Affordable Care Act (ACA) provision that blocks insurance companies from discriminating against those with pre-existing conditions, Ola was able to receive the lifesaving care she need without going bankrupt.   Ola is a fighter with a solid steel spine, and continues to be a fearless advocate for all those whose livelihoods are at risk if the Senate Republican bill passes. Tune in live as I join Ola and other Senate Democrats and their constituents to speak about what the Republican proposal means for her future and the lives of millions of others with pre-existing conditions across the country:

Today Senate Republicans voted to begin the process of ripping health care away from tens of millions of Americans. We have entered down a dangerous path. But this is not over—and we need you now more than ever to fight for all Americans who could lose their vital care. I'm joining my Democratic colleagues on the Senate steps to say: Don’t let up, keep fighting!

Senate Republicans just embarked on a very dangerous journey. If we don’t stop them, the end of this journey will be incredible damage and harm to our health care system. What they’ve done is light the fuse, and we need to make sure that the fire doesn’t travel down and blow up the health care system—denying health care to tens of millions of Americans to give a tax break to the wealthy few. It’s a three alarm fire. We need everybody to call, email, text, and show up at your Senator’s offices here and back home. We need to put out the fire before Republicans blow up our health care system.

Our fight is far from over. I know many of you are tired, but we must keep going: March, call, show up, text, tweet, and talk to your friends. We can't stop now—it’s up to all of us to ensure vital, affordable care for tens of millions of Americans.

We still have a chance to stop the Republicans’ destructive and dangerous health care plans. After a failed vote last night on an immoral proposal that combined the earlier bad Senate Republican plan with an amendment by Senator Ted Cruz, Senator Mitch McConnell will make a second attempt today to vote once again to rip health care away from tens of millions of Americans. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) has already shared that a repeal plan would leave 32 million American without health insurance and premiums would double. And later this week, we could see a vote on a “skinny” Trumpcare plan that would still cause enormous health cost increases for families across America, radically destabilizing the insurance marketplaces. One thing is clear: None of these plans will give Americans better care.   Tune in live as I head to the Senate floor to discuss why we can’t allow a vote to pass that will blow up our health care system. It’s time for the Senate Republicans to join Senate Democrats to take constructive, bipartisan actions to stabilize the insurance markets now.

Today, I joined my colleagues Senator Casey, Senator Hassan, Senator Duckworth and other advocates for people with disabilities in front of the Supreme Court to celebrate the 27th Anniversary of the passage of the historic Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). That landmark law was a big step forward for inclusion, dignity, civil rights and freedom in America. But our work is far from over.   At this moment, the goal of a more inclusive America—where everyone has a chance to succeed regardless of disability status—is under threat. The devastating cuts proposed to Medicaid in the Senate Republican plans would make it impossible for many people with disabilities to actually benefit from the gains made with the ADA.    Over 70 million Americans rely on Medicaid’s vital services, including the millions of Americans living with a disability. In the past, many people with disabilities were shunted into grim institutions and often denied basic human rights. The Medicaid program has allowed individuals with disabilities to live independently and with dignity in our community. It has also allowed individuals to get the life-saving treatment they need. The deep cuts to Medicaid cuts will put these individuals at risk, all to give tax cuts to powerful corporations and the wealthiest Americans.    That is not the America I know—in our country everybody counts and no one should be left behind. A few years ago, I was proud to work successfully with members on both sides of the aisle to pass the ABLE Act, which is now helping children with disabilities and their families plan and save for their futures. We need to celebrate the remarkable contributions that people with disabilities have made to our society rather than attempt to defund critical health care programs that help make America more inclusive.   The courage and tireless activism of those who came out today was inspiring—thanks for sharing your stories and for being a voice for millions of vulnerable Americans who couldn’t get involved in this fight, but deserve to be heard. Keep up the pressure, our fight isn’t over!

This week, after Senate Republicans’ tried and failed twice to take health care away from tens of millions of Americans—today Mitch McConnell will bring out yet another plan that’s been crafted in secret and under the cover of darkness. The Senate Majority Leader isn’t letting anyone know—including some of his Republican colleagues—about what’s going on. This is a bill that affects every American and one-sixth of our economy—and Senate Republicans’ were crafting it over lunch, behind closed doors. Did Senator McConnell not listen to Senator McCain’s plea for transparency?  At some point today, we are expecting to vote on what they call “skinny repeal”—something similar to what the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) reported will leave 16 million Americans uninsured. But don’t be fooled by the name—this bill is also rotten, proving once again that there’s no amount of perfume that can cover up this skunk. As Senate Republican leaders have made clear—they are not serious about this plan and it’s only a political game: they’ve made clear that their goal in advancing the “skinny repeal” is simply to pass something that will advance to a conference with the House. That way, GOP leaders can have more time to work yet again in secret and produce another unconscionable version of “repeal-and-replace” for final votes in the House and Senate. This is only a Trojan horse designed to slash Medicaid and put millions of lives and livelihoods at risk.  No matter the proposal, millions of Americans will be at risk of losing access to health care—and time and time again the CBO made that clear. We have a moral obligation to make sure everyone has access to care. It’s time we return to “regular order” with hearings and a bipartisan process. But, one thing’s for sure: we will keep fighting tooth and nail for a country in which every American has access to the health care they need.
Tune in as I give an update on the latest Senate Republicans' bill:

Thanks to everyone who fought so hard to make sure the Senate did the right thing on health care! Millions of voices from across Maryland and around the country were heard in the Senate Chamber last night when the final vote was cast at 1:40 am. As a result of all the rallies, phone calls, town halls, and emails, we were able to stop Senate Republican efforts that would have resulted in huge price spikes and millions of Americans losing access to affordable care—all to give tax breaks to the powerful few.   While we are relieved, we must remain vigilant. These zombie WealthCare bills have sprung back to life many times over the last seven months. In addition, President Trump has openly revealed that he will use every tool at his disposal to actively sabotage the Affordable Care Act (ACA).   I hope the Republican Senators and President Trump do not go down this road. Now is the time to roll up our sleeves and work together in a bipartisan way to improve health care for all Americans. Many of us have proposed common sense measures to immediately stabilize the Health Care Exchanges, as well as ideas to dramatically improve our overall health care system. The American people have spoken loud and clear. They do not want to reverse the progress we have made—they want to build on it in a way that makes affordable health care available to every American.

A year after the devastating flood, Ellicott City’s Main Street small business owners continue to rebuild. Ninety percent of the shops have reopened and the community has rallied to support these efforts. But the work is not done—and we should take steps to better protect the community from future floods and to better insure small business against large losses.  From Ellicott City to the Eastern Shore, flooding impacts communities across our state and Marylanders deserve a flood insurance program that is predictable, sustainable and affordable. In Ellicott City, there were many businesses who thought they were covered by the insurance policies they had purchased only to discover they were not. For example, many small business owners had paid for  "business interruption" insurance in the event their business was hit by a catastrophic event. However, many of them learned the hard way that their catastrophic coverage did not include flooding. The owners of the Southwest Connection and Fudge Shop on Main Street, for example, learned that their "business interruption" insurance policy covered civil unrest, fires, or an earthquake, but it did not cover losses from a flood.    That’s why I have introduced comprehensive, bipartisan legislation to extend the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) for six years while instituting a series of sweeping reforms to address the waste, abuse,  mismanagement and coverage gaps plaguing the system. We need to reform the National Flood Insurance Program to ensure that families and businesses have the affordable coverage they need, our flood maps are based on the most update-to-date science, and the NFIP program has long-term stability for communities across the country.

Last week the Senate overwhelmingly—and on bipartisan basis—passed the Countering America’s Adversaries Act, which imposes sanctions on Russia, Iran, and North Korea. This Act imposes tough economic penalties on Russia for its interference in our elections. Critically, the legislation prevents President Trump—who has repeatedly demonstrated his admiration for Vladimir Putin—from removing sanctions on Russia without the approval of the Congress. It sends a clear and unequivocal message to the Kremlin: the United States will not tolerate attacks on our democracy.  North Korea's increasingly aggressive and provocative actions also demand a strong response. Just last week North Korea fired another ballistic missile that experts say had the capacity to reach the U.S. mainland. That means they are on track to have the ability to strike the U.S. with a nuclear-armed missile much sooner than expected. The sanctions legislation passed by the Congress last week was a good first step toward increasing economic pressure on Pyongyang, but it left some big gaps that still need to be filled. Specifically, we need to take bolder steps to stop Chinese banks and other foreign financial institutions from doing business with North Korea. That is why Senator Pat Toomey and I have introduced bipartisan legislation entitled the Banking Restrictions Involving North Korea Act (BRINK). This legislation would give foreign banks and financial entities a simple choice: if they continue to do business with North Korea in violation of the existing international sanctions, they will lose access to the U.S in financial markets. It is time to get serious. We must bring North Korea to the negotiating table with the goal of eliminating nuclear weapons from the Korean Peninsula.

This is a time when Republicans and Democrats should be heeding Senator McCain's call to work together to strengthen our health care system and the good news is that Senator Alexander and Senator Murray just announced bipartisan hearings aimed at strengthening the Health Care Exchanges.  So it's time for President Trump to follow that example and stop taking steps to sabotage and destabilize the Health Care Exchanges. First, Trump should stop threatening to withhold the ongoing "cost sharing payments" that help lower the costs of health insurance. His threats have caused huge uncertainties that will lead to insurers leaving the marketplace or dramatically increasing premiums. Second, he needs to enforce the individual mandate/shared responsibility provisions of the ACA. The whole concept of insurance is that everybody needs to be part of the insurance pool in order to share risks across a large population. Otherwise, some people will freeload on the system and not pay their fair share. Third, he needs to instruct the Department of Health and Human Services to inform consumers about the health insurance options on the Health Care Exchanges so more people sign up.   Congress should also take bipartisan measures to improve the exchanges. I am sponsoring a number of practical proposals that have been proposed by U.S. Senate Democrats and look forward to input from our Republican colleagues on these and other bills.  Once we have resolved the immediate challenges of strengthening the exchanges, we should get to work on bolder measures to reduce the rising costs of prescription drugs and ensure quality, affordable care for all.  But before we can make things better, the President needs to stop his cynical efforts to make things worse!

At last week’s Senate Appropriations Hearing, Treasury Secretary Mnuchin claimed that President Trump’s budget proposal balances in 10 years. I think it’s important that the public and members of Congress know Mnuchin’s statement is simply false.   I’ve worked on a number of budgets throughout my career—serving as the ranking member of the House Committee on the Budget and now as a member of both the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committees. During that time, I have seen lots of the gimmicks that folks have used to support their budget numbers. I thought I had seen every trick in the book, but I’ve never seen anything that approaches blatant budget fraud like the Trump Budget.   The Trump Administration’s budget schemes would make the Enron accountants blush. But don’t just take it from me: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) scored the Trump budget and said it did not come close to balancing in ten years. While the Trump Administration claims a sizable budget surplus, the CBO concludes we would have a $720 billion deficit.  Budget projections should be based on data and realistic assumptions rather than fantasy or outright deceit. We can disagree about what policies we should pursue, but we shouldn't use dishonest accounting to hide the impact of those policies.

Earlier this week, I joined my Democratic colleagues to send a letter to President Trump, Majority Leader McConnell, and Chairman of the Finance Committee Orin Hatch urging Republicans to come to the table and work in a bipartisan way on the Senate’s next critical item—tax reform. I’m confident that, by working together, we could modernize our tax system to increase working families’ wages, improve job growth for working Americans, promote domestic investment, update our outdated business and international tax systems and put in place sound fiscal policies that raise the revenue needed to meet the needs of our country. But we are not interested in providing another round of windfall tax breaks to the wealthy few at the expense of everyone else —that’s not a priority in this country. Watch ↓ to find out what’s next in our fight for fair tax reform.

Diego and Lizandro Claros were children when they fled violence in El Salvador to seek a better life in the United States. They were exemplary Marylanders, prioritizing their educations and giving back to their community. It is important to go after gangs like MS-13, but it is an insult to decency and common sense for Diego and Lizandro to be targeted for deportation.   They were detained the other day when Lizandro followed the rules and asked immigration officials to have his case transferred from Maryland to North Carolina because he was offered a college scholarship there. Instead of congratulations, he and his brother were detained.   Our immigration system has been broken for too long, and we must work together in Congress to fix it. But Diego and Lizandro should not be the victims of Congress’s inaction—nor should they be victims of the Trump Administration’s disturbing efforts to punish those who have done nothing wrong. Unfortunately, despite our efforts, the Trump Administration rejected calls for compassion.   No one should be stoking fear and tearing apart hardworking immigrant families. Maryland and our nation were stronger with Diego and Lizandro contributing to our community, and my heart goes out to them and their family at this very difficult time.

Today, in response to President Trump’s reckless comments encouraging law enforcement to use excessive force, I joined many of my colleagues in asking Attorney General Jeff Sessions and the Department of Justice (DOJ) to follow the example of other law enforcement organizations and make clear that such conduct is unacceptable.   Most law enforcement officials conduct themselves with the highest integrity, respecting the rule of law and upholding the public trust. But Trump’s speech in Long Island last week—encouraging law enforcement officers to not be “too nice,” and describing how officers should rough up arrestees by banging their heads against police car roofs—mattered because his words openly encouraged bad actors to violate the principles of constitutional policing and norms of appropriate behavior.   Attorney General Sessions should follow the lead of the Acting Administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA),  Chuck Rosenberg, who urged his staff to disregard the President’s comments stating, “I write to offer a strong reaffirmation of the operating principles to which we, as law enforcement professionals, adhere. I write because we have an obligation to speak out when something is wrong. That’s what law enforcement officers do. … Our Core Values are clear and applicable: Rule of Law, respect, compassion, service, devotion, integrity, accountability, leadership, courage, and diversity. This is how we conduct ourselves. This is how we treat those whom we encounter in our work: victims, witnesses, subjects, and defendants. This is who we are.”   It is deeply disturbing for the President to call upon law enforcement to violate their constitutional duty and the public trust. Every public official who values the rule of law should speak out against the President's remarks—they do not reflect the traditions and values of policing in this country.

No childhood should be interrupted by a struggle for survival, but cancer tragically puts far too many kids in Maryland and across the country in a battle for their lives. That’s why back in February, I joined Senator Bennet, Senator Rubio, and Senator Gardner—along with a few of our House colleagues—to introduce a bill that would support the development of innovative and promising cancer drugs for children. And I’m pleased to announce that our bipartisan measure passed the Senate this week—a big win for kids and families coping with childhood cancer. It is now headed to the President’s desk for his signature. The Research to Accelerate Cures and Equity (RACE) for Children Act will modernize drug development regulations to help build on the progress being made at institutions like the National Institutes of Health (NIH). This is an important step in the right direction, but our job won’t be done until we are able to save every child—and their families—from the misery of this horrific disease.

This week, Attorney General Jeff Sessions told Baltimore officials that if the city wants to participate in federal programs designed to help cities combat violent crime—they must enforce the Trump Administration’s immigration enforcement orders that Maryland Attorney General Brian Frosh says could be unconstitutional and which are within the control of the State of Maryland, not the City of Baltimore. It's a gross abuse of power for purely political purposes and the Maryland congressional delegation will do everything in our power to reverse it.   The Justice Department’s mission is to ensure public safety and control crime—so it’s unconscionable that Sessions would threaten to withhold critical law enforcement support that could help reduce violent crime in Baltimore and other cities. Immigration enforcement is a matter for the federal government—and the Trump Administration has no right to try to commandeer the resources of the Baltimore City Police for strictly federal purposes. But there are two other reasons that make Sessions' demand especially outrageous in the case of Baltimore City. First, the Maryland Attorney General has warned Baltimore and other Maryland jurisdictions that they could be found liable for violating constitutional protections if they enforce the order from the Trump Administration to detain persons suspected of immigration violations for more than 48 hours. Second, it appears that Sessions overlooked the important fact that the Baltimore City jail is run by the State Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, not the Baltimore City Police Department. Therefore, Sessions is demanding that Baltimore Police Chief Kevin Davis and the Baltimore City Police take actions that are outside their control.  Rather than threatening Baltimore and other cities, the Justice Department should be doing what it can to support efforts to reduce violent crime. That's why all of us who are part of Baltimore’s Federal Delegation have called upon to Sessions to reverse this decision. As we await a response, we remain committed to helping Baltimore City secure needed resources in its effort to fight violent crime and strengthen community policing.

As the documentary STEP is headed to box offices across the country this weekend, I wanted to take a moment to share my experience meeting many of the young women in the film and watching their deeply insightful and emotional story. “Step” chronicles the trials and triumphs of three young women in a Baltimore high school step team, who are preparing to be the first in their families to go to college.   One of the striking things about stepping is the power in the movements. The stomping, clapping, and rhythm convey strength in every beat—and it’s only magnified throughout the team. So it’s fitting that step is central to the story of these extraordinary young women who go to the Baltimore Leadership School for Young Women, become “Lethal Ladies”, and realize their remarkable strength.   I’m proud to have Blessin, Cori, Tayla, and Coach G representing Baltimore on the big screen—they are an example of the goals and dreams that motivate so many of our young people. I want to thank them all for sharing their stories and reminding young women across the country to believe in themselves and the amazing things they can do.

From 2011 to 2015 Wells Fargo opened millions of fraudulent accounts—more than two million bank accounts and 565,000+ credit card accounts—in its customers’ names. Since then, significant developments related to the bank’s misconduct continue to emerge—including the fact that more customers than previously thought were impacted by the fake accounts scam and that the bank may have retaliated against their own employees. But it doesn’t just stop there: Wells Fargo is now attempting to use forced arbitration clauses that the company tucked away in the fine print of contracts—which their customers signed when they opened legitimate accounts—to block them from suing over the fraudulent accounts.   We must immediately demand answers from the bank's leadership. That's why last week, a number of my Democratic colleagues and I asked for a hearing with Wells Fargo CEO Timothy Sloan and Board of Directors Chairman Stephen Sanger so we can question them about what Wells Fargo is doing to compensate victims of the fake-accounts scandal and recent revelations that the bank may have charged nearly a million customers for auto insurance they did not want.   While we wait to hear back from the Senate Banking Committee Chairman Mike Crapo about our requested hearing, it’s essential that victims of Wells Fargo’s fraudulent activities have their day in court. I’m proud to join U.S. Senator Sherrod Brown to introduce the Justice for Victims of Fraud Act which will help make that happen. I will continue to make sure Congress works to strengthen consumer protections and hold big banks accountable so they don’t cheat customers just so their CEOs can pocket millions.

Every four years the Federal Science Steering Committee (SSC)—comprised of many of Maryland’s own federal agencies, including the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration—completes a report detailing the impact of climate change and its physical effects on our country. The The New York Times published a draft copy of this year’s sweeping report, which directly contradicts claims by the Trump Administration that climate change isn’t a real and urgent threat. Unlike the Trump Administration’s claims that climate change is a hoax, this report is rooted in scientific fact. It examines every corner the United States, finding that Americans are feeling the effects of climate change right now. In fact, the report concludes that average temperatures in the United States have risen drastically since 1980, and recent decades have been the warmest of the past 1,500 years. While the authors don’t make policy recommendations, they warn that rising levels of greenhouse gases will be harmful to our health and that, as sea levels rise, our coastal economies will be devastated.     Scientists fear that the Trump Administration will suppress or change the report—but since it’s now public we must make sure the American people have the facts to fight back if this happens. We’ve seen how a public outcry recently pressured the Environmental Protection Agency’s (EPA) to move forward with new ozone standards—and together we can do it again. So please share this to build public awareness and fight back against those who would deny the reality of climate change and the need to take action to protect our future.

Yesterday, we learned that North Korea may have crossed another critical threshold in its nuclear weapons program by producing a miniaturized nuclear warhead that could fit atop a missile. This comes just a few weeks after North Korea tested an Intercontinental Ballistic Missile (ICBM), which experts believe could reach the U.S. mainland.   These developments demand a strong response and the latest round of additional United Nations (U.N.) sanctions on North Korea are an important step in building international pressure on the country. However, U.N. sanctions resolutions are only words on a piece of paper if they are not actually enforced. In fact, there are already broad U.N. sanctions in place against North Korea, but they have been ignored by financial institutions and businesses in many countries, especially in China. The failure of China and some other countries to enforce U.N. sanctions has reduced the economic pressure needed to get North Korean to engage in meaningful negotiations to end their nuclear programs.  That's why Senator Pat Toomey and I introduced bipartisan legislation—modeled after the successful Iran sanctions laws—to give real teeth to the U.N. sanctions regime. Our bill, the BRINK Act, offers foreign firms a stark choice: You can do business with the United States or with North Korea, but you can’t to do business with both. It is time to let Chinese and other firms know that if they continue to flout U.N. sanctions on North Korea, they will forfeit their access to the U.S. market.    The stakes are far too high for President Trump’s dangerous and irresponsible threats of war. Right now the real danger is the uncertainty created by Trump’s words, which are undermining our country’s credibility. Engaging in a war of words with Kim Jong Un plays into his hands. It elevates the North Korean dictator and diminishes the President of the United States. President Trump should follow the wise counsel of former President Teddy Roosevelt who said "speak softly and carry a big stick." This moment requires steady and firm American leadership, not overheated rhetoric. The Trump Administration should devise a coherent strategy that combines economic sanctions and rigorous diplomacy to peacefully resolve the North Korean nuclear crisis.

Democratic Senators have been meeting with folks in every part of our states and we're all hearing the same thing: Too many Americans are feeling squeezed between flat or sinking paychecks on the one hand, and rising costs and prices on the other. But it’s not enough to simply analyze or empathize with these challenges—we must have a plan to do something about it. That’s why House Democrats and U.S. Senate Democrats are laying out an economic plan that will give Americans A Better Deal on everything from raising paychecks to reducing the costs of certain necessities. One key part of our plan will reduce the skyrocketing cost of prescription drugs, which have become unaffordable for too many of our constituents and working people across the country.   I sat down with my friend and leader on this issue, U.S. Senator Al Franken to talk about our plans to lower the cost of prescription drugs. Watch ↓ and share.

Yesterday, President Trump applauded Russian President Vladimir Putin for his decision to force the United States to slash our embassy and consulate staff in Russia by 755 people. Trump said, “I want to thank him because we’re trying to cut down on payroll, and as far as I’m concerned, I’m very thankful that he let go of a large number of people because now we have a smaller payroll.”    As the co-chair of the bipartisan Senate Foreign Service Caucus with Senator Dan Sullivan, and as the son of a Foreign Service Officer myself, I know firsthand the immense impact our diplomats have on promoting American security, interests, and values abroad. Our President should be honoring our foreign service officers, who work tirelessly on behalf of our country—in nearly 300 embassies, consulates, and diplomatic missions around the world. These men and women often take great personal risks to advance our interests and they help keep America safe by resolving conflicts that prevent American soldiers from going to war. They are also on the front lines of our efforts to promote the ideals of democracy, human rights, liberty, opportunity and equality around the world.   In the history of our Republic, no American president has routinely sided with a foreign adversary over the interests of his own country. This again begs the questions—why is Trump so eager to please Putin? And is there anything Putin does that Trump doesn't like?

Hate kills. No ambiguity. One of John F. Kennedy's favorite quotes was "The hottest places in Hell are reserved for those who in time of moral crisis preserve their neutrality." We must speak out and condemn racism, neo-nazism and white supremacy in all their forms. #Notbothsides #Stopthehate  #Charlottesville

There can be no neutrality when it comes to confronting evil. President Trump's repugnant reasoning today has already drawn praise from David Duke, the KKK, white supremacists, and neo-Nazis who brought their hate to Charlottesville. This is a repulsive and sad moment for the institution of the presidency.   The situation is crystal clear. One side holds swastikas, encourages violence against those that don’t look like them, and carries the burning torch of hatred. The other side is fighting against bigotry, racism, and is pushing progress forward no matter how hard it is. This is a moment in history that demands the utmost moral clarity, not appeasement of neo-Nazis and white supremacists. The arc of the moral universe bends toward justice. We will not let President Trump reverse our journey toward a more perfect union.    I call on all Americans, regardless of their political stripes, to come together as patriots to demand an apology from President Trump and to denounce hate in all its forms.

In the past year, there has been an explosive rise in the number of hate groups in the United States. In fact, the Southern Poverty Law Center has found that hate groups operating in the United States have increased by 25 percent since 2016. Even more startling, anti-Muslim hate groups have almost tripled since last year. This hate movement—which has been growing rapidly—is one that fosters anti-Muslim, anti-Semitic, anti-immigrant, anti-multiculturalism, and racist rhetoric. This is a white supremacist movement and one that President Trump has not only refused to denounce—but has also refused to take action against. In fact, he has engaged in a narrative of false moral equivalence between those perpetuating hate and those confronting it.   Back in April, my Democratic colleagues and I wrote to the President asking him to create a Presidential Task Force to prevent and combat hate crimes. He didn’t respond. It was only until after the horrific events in Charlottesville that Trump decided to create a subcommittee, part of the Department of Justice’s Task Force on Crime Reduction and Public Safety that will “develop a plan to appropriately address hate crimes.” While this is a positive development, it’s simply not enough to create a small subcommittee and provide no details on how it will actually address hate crimes.    Which is why my Democratic colleagues and I have written to Attorney General Jeff Sessions urging him to create a full Presidential Task Force to help combat hate based incidents and violence. In addition to an interagency task force to combat hate based incidents and violence, we are also urging Sessions to devote resources to support states and local communities in addressing the root causes of hate through education, community development, and cross-cultural exchanges.    In recent weeks, the Trump Administration has taken steps to decrease funding for efforts to stop white extremism, as evidenced by the Department of Homeland Security pulling funding for Life After Hate, a group dedicated to de-radicalizing neo-Nazis and stopping white extremism. With activity involving white extremist and hate groups on the rise in our country, now is not the time to shift our resources away from funding efforts to combat these hateful organizations that threaten to undermine our democracy. While I wait to hear back from the Trump Administration about their plan to prevent and combat hate crimes in America, share this helpful resource on steps we can all take to fight back against hate.

This week, The Baltimore Sun reported that Kushner Companies—owned by Trump’s son-in-law and White House Senior Advisor Jared Kushner—is using aggressive debt-collection tactics on its current and former tenants, including asking judges to arrest people who owe their company money. In Maryland alone, Kushner Companies has sought the arrest of 105 former tenants. This is particularly harsh considering that Kushner Companies receives federal rental subsidies and financing from Freddie Mac so that they can serve low-income renters. What’s even worse is that a report from The New York Times and ProPublica found that Kushner Co. didn’t even provide their tenants with housing that abides by federal standards—including failing housing inspections for unsafe and unsanitary conditions. The report told the stories of struggling families who suffered for years at the hands of Kushner Companies and revealed the company's long history as an unscrupulous and unresponsive landlord to thousands of largely lower-income tenants in Maryland, New Jersey, and Ohio.   These reports raise very serious and troubling concerns about whether Kushner Companies and its subsidiaries are complying with federal housing quality standards to ensure the safety and health of their tenants. That’s why this week the Maryland Democratic Delegation and I wrote a letter to Kushner Companies requesting documents relating to multiple reports that the company and its subsidiaries may be violating the requirements of a federally funded housing program operated by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). While we wait to hear back, if you’ve been impacted by abusive rental practices I want to hear from you. Please send me a note to me at www.vanhollen.senate.gov/content/contact-senator.

I just got back from a bipartisan congressional delegation trip organized by Senator Edward J. Markey—we traveled to South Korea, China, and Japan to identify strategies for getting North Korea to immediately freeze its testing of nuclear weapons and missiles and bring them to the negotiating table with the goal of eliminating nuclear weapons on the Korean Peninsula. To do so, we must work with others to dramatically increase the economic pressure on North Korea. That effort must include penalizing the foreign banks and financial firms that help prop up the North Korean economy. In addition, China should cut off its oil exports to North Korea. Watch ↓ as Chris Jansing and I discuss how President Trump needs to dial down the rhetoric and dial up the economic pressure on North Korea.

This Women's Equality Day, let's recommit to fighting back against any effort by the Trump Administration to roll back women's rights. Our fight to make sure women across the country have full equality is far from over, we must persist!

In his American classic, Woody Guthrie said it best: "This land is your land, this land is my land." The Trump Administration wants to change these lyrics to: "This land is no longer your land; this land now belongs to special interests and the oil companies."  We must fight the ongoing effort of President Trump and Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke to take public lands away from the American people and turn them over to commercial special interests by eliminating portions of some of our precious National Monuments. The proposals to sell these national monuments to drilling, mining, logging, and other special interests will result in the loss of millions of acres of hunting, fishing and camping opportunities while destroying some of our most priceless archaeological sites. So far, over 2.7 million public comments have poured in during the Department of the Interior’s 60-day comment period—a record-breaking response that was overwhelming in support of protecting our national monuments. The Trump Administration should listen to the millions of Americans who spoke up to say: "This land is your land, this land is my land."

Maryland stands with all those being hit by Hurricane Harvey, which has continued its relentless devastation this past weekend with catastrophic flooding in Houston. It’s been a heartbreaking time for our friends in Texas, but the overwhelming amount of support across the country has shown our country’s true light: during difficult times, Americans help each other out no matter what. Here is how you, or friends you know across the country, can show solidarity and help those impacted by Hurricane Harvey:

Yesterday the Trump Administration announced that they will resume handing out excess military gear—including bayonets, grenade launchers, and tracked armored vehicles—to local law enforcement departments across the country. This move will not make us any safer. Now is a time when we need to focus on effective community policing not the militarization of our police. Our police don’t need grenade launchers to protect themselves or our communities. We need to build communities of trust, not war zones. I intend to work with Senator Rand Paul and others to reverse this dangerous step backwards. Share this with your friends and family, to make sure we have a unified front against the Trump Administration’s dangerous step backwards.

This is a great example of what we can accomplish with innovative private-public partnerships. So proud of the work Johns Hopkins University, Warby Parker, Baltimore City Health Department, Vision To Learn, and Baltimore City Public Schools are doing to improve the reading proficiency gap in Baltimore. Good job all!

This week, 19-year-old underdog Frances Tiafoe took on tennis superstar Roger Federer in the first-round of the U.S. Open—and played an amazing game. If you didn’t catch it, it’s worth watching the jaw-dropping match—Tiafoe’s missile of a forehand and otherworldly topspin does not disappoint. However, what you might not know about Tiafoe is that he grew up in Maryland and spent most of his childhood tirelessly practicing on the courts of College Park’s Junior Tennis Champions Center. He often stayed there with his father, who worked as the maintenance man, when they had no other home. Tiafoe, the son of immigrants from the West African nation of Sierra Leone, has emerged as the nation’s most buzzed about tennis prodigy. His story is worth taking the time to read and share—it’s a great Maryland success story.

Yesterday, President Trump traveled to the "Show Me State" of Missouri to talk about his tax plan—but, for all the hype, he had very little to show. The White House has refused to release any real details on their proposal, but the little information they have shared leaves me concerned that this is just more repackaged Trickle Down Economics. Based on the outline of their plan, if your last name is Trump, this plan is great for your bottom line. But if you’re one of the millions of people who have been left behind by this economy, the President’s proposal only makes your problems worse. His plan provides a huge giveaway to himself—and leaves working Americans and future generations to pay the bill. Instead of offering more tax breaks to wealthy, powerful special interests, we must level the playing field for hardworking Americans and build an economy that helps everyone get ahead.  I’ve joined my Democratic colleagues in laying out clear principles for tax reform that actually helps working Americans. First, no tax plan should increase the tax burden on the middle class and there should be absolutely no tax cut for the top 1% wealthiest households. Second, tax reform should go through the normal legislative process so both Democrats and Republicans have an opportunity to craft a bipartisan package. If we’ve learned anything from the Republicans’ health care debacle, it’s that crafting legislation in a secret, hyper-partisan fashion is a recipe for disaster. Third, tax reform shouldn’t add to the federal deficit—and the analysis of the deficit impact must come from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO), not fraudulent, Enron-style accounting that hides a huge cost to working families.  Democrats stand ready to work with the Trump Administration and Republicans if they are ready to put working Americans before wealthy special interests. Unfortunately, Trump's speech appeared to be a tax play that lifts the yachts but sinks the rest of the boats.

In April 2016, after a robust public debate, then-Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew announced that Harriet Tubman would replace President Andrew Jackson on the face of the twenty-dollar bill, whose likeness would move to the reverse side. She would be the first African-American ever on our paper currency and the only woman on our currently-circulated bills. Tubman is fully deserving of this honor, but today Secretary Mnuchin refused to commit to moving this important project forward. This is shameful.   Born in Dorchester County, Maryland as a slave, Tubman escaped to freedom and returned to rescue others as part of the Undergound Railroad. She served the Union Army as a spy and a nurse during the Civil War and spent the rest of her life fighting for women’s suffrage, the care of orphans and individuals with disabilities, and the establishment of freedman’s schools. Making this change in 2020, which is the 100th anniversary of the ratification of the 19th Amendment, sends a powerful signal.    Those we honor on currency make a statement about our nation and our values. Which is why Senator Ben Cardin and I sent a letter to Mnuchin this afternoon urging him to move forward with putting Tubman on the twenty-dollar bill—making a strong statement about our nation’s commitment to equality and justice.

Today I think about Jorge Steven Acuña’s story. In 2001, when Steven was just 8 years old, his family came to the United States after his mother began receiving death threats. For nearly 16 years since arriving from Colombia, Jorge and his family have lived and worked in this country as productive, law-abiding citizens. But in 2012, having been denied the political asylum they sought in America, they were yanked from their Germantown home and locked up in a detention center on Maryland’s Eastern Shore.   The Acuña family reached out to my Congressional office and we joined forces with advocacy organizations, immigration lawyers, and local leaders to make sure they stayed where they belonged—right here in Maryland. And thanks to the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, Steven just graduated with a bachelor’s degree in chemical engineering from the University of Maryland and aspires to be an orthopedic surgeon.   The Trump Administration’s decision to rescind the DACA program is taking our country backwards. Over its five-year history, DACA has helped nearly 800,000 young people pursue higher education and grow our economy. Ending this program will cost our economy over $460.3 billion over ten years and displace over 685,000 workers vital to businesses in Maryland and across the nation.   It's important to go after gangs like MS-13, but it is an insult to decency and common sense for Dreamers, like Steven, to be targeted for deportation. At its core, America exists because people seeking freedom worked hard to build a better life. Dreamers today deserve that same chance. They came out of the shadows because of their desire to get an education and contribute to our country, and in turn, our government promised to protect them. It would go against the nation’s founding ideals to break that promise. We cannot let the Trump Administration get away with tearing apart innocent families and wreaking havoc on our economy in Maryland.

Around the country, Americans are standing with the residents of Houston, Texas and the Gulf Coast as they face unprecedented flooding and devastation from Hurricane Harvey. As we work to provide the federal support needed to help rebuild after this storm, it is more important than ever that we extend the authorization for the National Flood Insurance Program (which expires at the end of this month) AND, at the same time, reform that program to fix its serious shortcomings. Changes are necessary to address the waste, abuse, limitations and mismanagement plaguing the current system.    In the article below, you’ll see how small business owners in Ellicott City, Maryland struggled to rebuild their businesses after last year’s flood. Many businesses thought they were covered by the insurance policies they had purchased, only to discover they were simply out of luck after the storm. That’s why I’ve introduced comprehensive, bipartisan legislation to ensure that families and businesses have the affordable coverage they need, that our flood maps are based on the most update-to-date science, and that the NFIP program has long-term stability for communities across the country.

This Labor Day let's remember those hard working men and women who fought so hard to ensure workers' rights that we sometimes take for granted—like overtime pay, the 40 hour work week and many workplace safety rules. At the same time, let us rededicate ourselves to strengthening the ability of unions to grow and bargain for fair pay and benefits. We also need to fight to increase the federal minimum wage, grow our economy in a way that expands the middle class, and enact equal pay for equal work.  Last week we saw the Trump Administration take a step backwards in our battle for equal pay when they announced that it would no longer enforce an Obama-era rule that requires businesses with more than 100 employees to provide information on wages by gender and race to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC). This data helped the federal government track wage discrimination and address pay disparities among workers of different genders, races, and ethnic groups. Ending wage transparency makes it harder to ensure equal pay—plain and simple. And for women and families, equal pay isn’t just about fairness. It can mean the difference between being able to put food on the table, pay for childcare, or save for retirement.  This Labor Day, let's take the time to talk about this important issue with our families and friends. As we’ve seen with other key legislative fights, public opinion has the ultimate power to sway our country in the right direction and we need to fully engage the American public in this battle to ensure that every American receives a fair day's pay for equal work.

Today President Trump pulled the plug on Dreamers—the more than 800,000 young people who were brought to the United States as infants, toddlers, or kids, and have grown up pledging allegiance to the United States of America. These individuals have done nothing wrong. In fact, they have done everything America has asked of them. They are now preparing for productive careers, or already working for American businesses, or serving in our Armed Forces. President Trump's decision was a gratuitously cruel and unnecessary act. The President's harmful decision now demands an immediate response from the Republican-controlled Senate and House. In the Senate, we have a bipartisan bill introduced by Senators Lindsay Graham and Dick Durbin called the Dream Act of 2017—I’m a strong supporter of that bill and we should pass it immediately. We should send a strong message that American will stand with those who call America home and that we will not punish those who have done nothing wrong.

On a very bleak day in Washington, I was pleased to start the morning on a high note by visiting with Maryland students and educators on their first day back at school. Joined with Montgomery County Executive Ike Leggett and principals—at both Paint Branch High School and Jackson Road Elementary School—to greet students and teachers. As we say goodbye to summer and embrace a new school year, let’s remember the wise words of Maryland’s teacher of the year, Sia Kyriakakos, “Teaching art isn’t only about color and lines; it’s about equity of knowledge and opening a world of possibilities to our students.” I’m urging Maryland educators to heed her advice and open a new world of knowledge for all students.

I’m ready to fight like hell for the 800,000 Dreamers across this country. Are you with me? Tune in to hear about next steps in our fight to pass the Dream Act of 2017 and Jorge Steven Acuña’s story, one of Maryland’s own Dreamers.

Today’s announcement that the Department of Education plans to rewrite key Title IX guidance—which works to address and prevent sexual assault in our schools—is a step in the wrong direction. College campuses should be safe havens where young Marylanders are able to learn and grow, but the threat of sexual violence is still a troubling reality in our state and across the country. I’ve worked on a bipartisan basis to create safer learning environments, and we have more to do. But instead of working with us to make the system safer and stronger, Secretary DeVos is perpetuating a false narrative that sexual assault isn’t a serious problem that should be addressed in this country. One in five women will be sexually assaulted during her college career. That’s an inexcusable statistic and we must do better to stop this.  We should be doing everything in our power to eradicate sexual assault on college campuses. It’s up to us to stand up and tell the Trump Administration that we refuse to go backwards. I will fight these efforts to roll back the progress we’ve made in the Senate, and continue to push to make colleges a safe place for our children to build successful lives and careers—but make your views know too, talk to your friends and family. We all can, and must, do better to eradicate the stigma attached to talking about sexual assault. We must stand up and fight back.

Let me get this straight: Equifax had a huge security breach—exposing sensitive financial information of up to 143 million Americans—and then tricked their customers into giving up their legal rights by signing up for their free credit monitoring services? That’s outrageous and a reminder of why we must fight efforts to roll back the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau’s new rule that would prevent companies like Equifax and Wells Fargo from scamming their customers—and give people the right to sue if they’ve been wronged. I’m calling on the Senate Banking Committee to hold a hearing immediately—we must get to the bottom of this issue. Today, all across America, we honor those whose lives were taken from us in the brutal terrorist attacks sixteen years ago, including the brave first responders who sacrificed their own lives to save others.Those who attacked us sought to divide us. Instead, Americans responded by uniting as one to rebuild and fight back.  As we memorialize those we lost, let us rededicate ourselves to reaching out as neighbors to help those in need. We are witnessing that unity in the response to the victims of Hurricanes Harvey and Irma. Here, in every part of Maryland, thousands of volunteers are devoting their time and talent to help others in our community. Today, I was honored to join The 6th Branch, a veterans-led service group in Baltimore City, as they gathered hundreds of volunteers to participate in the Together We Serve 9/11 Day of Service, working to support schools and neighborhoods in East Baltimore. Sixteen years ago, our hearts were broken, but not our resolve. Let us recommit ourselves to working together for the American we love.

Around the country, Americans stand with the residents of Texas, Florida, U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, and the Gulf Coast as they face unprecedented flooding from Hurricane Harvey and devastation from Hurricane Irma. As we work to provide the federal support they need to save lives and rebuild after this storm, it is more important than ever to ensure our roads, bridges, and other critical infrastructures are able to withstand the impacts of flooding.   Despite support from groups ranging from environmentalists to the insurance industry, President Trump has decided to ignore the clear and growing issue of flood prevention and management. Just weeks before Hurricane Harvey ripped through communities on the Gulf Coast, Trump signed an Executive Order that rescinded an Obama-era rule which would have ensured that infrastructure projects are built to survive the impacts of climate change, including flooding and rising sea levels. It was a common sense measure designed to protect our nation’s infrastructure, conserve taxpayer resources, safeguard businesses from flood damage, and keep communities safe.   The destruction facing the Gulf Coast—like major storms in other communities—serve as a stark reminder that we must prepare our nation’s critical infrastructure to deal with flooding. If we don’t invest when our roads and bridges are being built, we risk the lives of American families and ultimately spend more taxpayer dollars to repair them after floods occur.   Which is why I’m joining forces with Senator Brian Schatz and Cory Booker to restore the important protections that had been in place to safeguard American lives and taxpayers.  Today we are introducing legislation to stop the Trump Administration from turning back the clock on these common sense flood standards by making them permanent under the law.

No childhood should be interrupted by a struggle for survival, but cancer tragically puts far too many kids in Maryland and across the country in a battle for their lives. Although we’ve made important progress, cancer remains the leading cause of death from disease among children. Congress must do more to help children and families coping with this disease. I’ve recently worked across the aisle to pass the Research to Accelerate Cures and Equity (RACE) for Children Act, which will build on the progress being made at institutions like the Children's National Medical Center and National Institutes of Health (NIH). This is an important step in the right direction, but our job won’t be done until we are able to save every child—and their families—from the misery of this horrific disease.    This week I was honored to have the opportunity to visit doctors, staff, and patients and their family members at Children’s National to mark Childhood Cancer Awareness Month. I participated in the Treats and Treasures program and tried to bring a bit of joy to the children who are staying in the hospital. I want to thank the team at Children's National for having me and I look forward to working with these great advocates in this fight against childhood cancer.

Too many parents are being squeezed between flat play checks and the very high costs of child care. No parent should have to choose between having a job and ensuring that their children have quality care. That's why Congress must act to ensure that every family has access to quality, affordable child care. Which is why U.S. Senate Democrats and I are introducing the Child Care for Working Families Act. This legislation would give hardworking American families the peace of mind to know they can afford quality care for their kids and help more children succeed from the start. If you’ve been impacted by the skyrocketing costs of child care, please share your story with me in the comments below. Just as personal stories helped us stop the repeal of the Affordable Care Act, your stories can play an important role in our effort to pass this legislation.

Today is Harriet Tubman Day, and we must fight to make sure her tremendous contributions are properly honored. Last year the Obama Administration announced that Tubman’s image would be placed on the front of the twenty-dollar bill. But just a few weeks ago, Treasury Secretary Mnuchin revealed that he wasn’t “committed” to that plan. Immediately after his remarks, Senator Ben Cardin and I sent a letter to Mnuchin—urging him to move forward with this project. It’s been almost a month and we have yet to receive a response. The fact that Mnuchin won't affirm the promise to place Tubman on the twenty-dollar bill is yet another bad signal coming out of the Trump Administration. If this Administration were interested in bringing people together, they would recognize the importance of celebrating the historical achievements of a great American patriot like Tubman.  Those we honor on our currency make a statement about our nation’s values. Tubman was tireless in her pursuit of freedom and protection of human rights, and she represents the best in Maryland and our entire country. It's time we recognize Tubman’s place in history by putting her on the twenty-dollar bill. That's why I am asking you to speak up and tell the Trump Administration that it’s time to put Tubman on the twenty-dollar bill. Fifty years ago this week, Thurgood Marshall became the first African American to serve as a Supreme Court Justice. Marshall was born and raised in Baltimore, where his father would often listen to legal cases at the local courthouse and return home to rehash the lawyers' arguments with his two sons. Marshall credited these formative years as the foundation for his interest in civil rights and the law.  After graduating from college, Marshall applied to the University of Maryland Law School—but, despite being qualified academically, was rejected because of the color of his skin. But Marshall wasn’t deterred in his fight for equal justice under the law and later attended Howard University Law School. In 1934, soon after graduating Howard, he worked in the legal division of the NAACP. He filed dozens of lawsuits and argued dozens of cases in the effort to overturn segregation. Two years later, Marshall took on the role of the NAACP’s chief counsel. In that role, he ultimately succeeded in bringing the Brown v. Board of Education case before the Supreme Court and securing a monumental ruling against segregation in public schools.  In 1965, President Lyndon B. Johnson appointed Marshall to be the United States Solicitor General. Working for the Department of Justice, he won 14 out of the 19 cases that he argued before the Supreme Court. And in 1967, President Johnson nominated Marshall to be a Supreme Court Justice. As Johnson put it, “Marshall symbolizes what is best about our American society: the belief that human rights must be satisfied through the orderly processes of law.” During his 24 years on the Court, Marshall consistently challenged discrimination based on race or sex, opposed the death penalty, supported the rights of criminal defendants, defended affirmative action, and championed women’s rights.  Marshall embodied a commitment to equal justice under the law—something that’s more important than ever. Let’s honor his work by staying true to his words: “America must get to work. In the chilled climate in which we live, we must go against the prevailing winds. We must dissent from the indifference. We must dissent from the apathy. We must dissent from the fear, the hatred, and the mistrust. We must dissent from a nation that buried its head in the sand waiting in vain for the needs of its poor, its elderly, and its sick to disappear and just blow away. We must dissent from a government that has left its young without jobs, education, or hope. We must dissent from the poverty of vision and timeless absence of moral leadership. We must dissent, because America can do better, because America has no choice but to do better.”

With everything going on these days, you may have missed the debate and votes in the Senate Budget Committee this week. But that vote was the first step in the Republican effort to fast-track a tax plan that will provide a windfall tax break to the top 1% at the expense of everyone and everything else.   During the debate, Senate Republicans were quick to pay lip service to helping working families—but their budget and tax plan does the opposite. In fact, Senate Republicans voted AGAINST an amendment offered by me and Kamala Harris to ensure that the GOP plan will not increase taxes on the middle class.   The GOP budget takes a sledgehammer to Medicare, Medicaid, and education funding in order to finance windfall tax breaks for millionaires and billionaires. Trust me—it can be hard to follow all the moving parts in their proposal. That’s why, over the coming weeks, I’ll be reporting on different components of the GOP budget.   Today’s topic: how the Republican budget will eliminate the estate tax, the estate tax—something that only impacts two-tenths of 1%  percent of taxpayer estates—is a longstanding feature of our tax code. Today, individuals with estates below $5.6 million and couples with estates below $11 million pay zero estate tax. Not one penny. The estate tax impacts only about 5,000 taxpayers a year—in the entire country. The wealthiest of the wealthy.   Teddy Roosevelt would be rolling in his grave at the Republican effort to completely eliminate the estate tax. It is designed to ensure that America does not become a place dominated by aristocratic family dynasties that accumulate ever larger shares of our national wealth. And that's why I often call it a "dynasty tax." We already have seen wealth inequality grow at an alarming scale. Today, the top 0.1% of households have almost as much wealth as 90 percent of the rest of the country put together. Eliminating the dynasty tax will simply accelerate this inequality.   Who benefits from eliminating the dynasty tax? People like President Trump. In fact, according to Bloomberg, it would save the President’s estate between $564 million and $2 billion. Providing this tax windfall to people like Trump will add $240 billion to our national debt over the next 10 years. That cost will be added to our national credit card to be paid by our children and grandchildren.   I proposed an amendment to block any budget that would repeal the dynasty tax, but every single one of my Republican colleagues on the Budget Committee voted against it even as they voted for a budget that would cut $1 trillion from Medicaid and almost $500 billion from Medicare.   The debate over the budget may not be the most exciting topic—but it's amongst the most consequential. The GOP budget is harmful to our future. We must fight it with all of the energy we’ve got. Are you with me Maryland?

We need to grow Maryland’s rural economy—and one way to do that is through expanded access to broadband. Nationally, 23 million rural Americans do not have internet service available to them at adequate speed, quality, and price. Economic opportunities are often limited in areas without broadband, which is why the government and private sector need to work together to address this issue. I’m working with my colleagues in support of a $40 billion federal investment to build the kind of broadband infrastructure that will finally connect rural communities.   However, it’s also critical that broadband service providers deliver fair and equal access to all users regardless of zip code. You see, many rural areas do not have access to fixed broadband, which is delivered through a landline or cable. It’s more expensive for telecommunication companies to install—and instead of making the necessary investments to help grow our rural economies, they have asked the FCC to change the rules so they can claim they have met their responsibilities by providing wireless coverage to rural areas. The problem is that wireless broadband is generally slower, less reliable, and more expensive for consumers than fixed broadband.  I raised this issue recently at an Agriculture Committee Hearing on rural economic development. I asked the Trump Administration to join me in asking the FCC not to change the rule in a way that shortchanges rural areas. So far, they have not responded.

We face a real crisis with North Korea, but President Trump's response has been to publicly berate Secretary of State Tillerson for his efforts at diplomacy. Then, as if the North Korean crisis is not enough, Trump appears ready to reject the advice of Secretary of Defense Mattis and manufacture a nuclear crisis with Iran. According to reports, this week Trump will take a reckless step that could inevitably lead to the unraveling of the 2015 nuclear agreement with Iran that was also signed by Britain, France, Germany, the European Union, China, and Russia. That dangerous act would harm our national security interests and lead us closer to war.   The Iran deal is working. It has verifiably shut off Iran’s pathways to a nuclear bomb, imposed tough constraints on Iran’s nuclear program, and subjected Iran to the most comprehensive inspection and monitoring regime ever negotiated. We also know that Iran is in compliance with the agreement. Indeed, the Trump Administration has twice certified Iran’s compliance with the deal and waived nuclear-related sanctions on Iran just a few weeks ago. Our State Department, our Defense Department, and our Intelligence Community have all assessed that Iran is in compliance with the nuclear agreement. Just today the respected head of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) confirmed again that Iran is meeting its obligations. And guess what: Trump has presented NO evidence to Congress—as he is required to do by law—of any potential Iranian breach of the deal.   Make no mistake: Trump’s reasons for not certifying Iran’s compliance are based on political petulance, not national security. He wants to rip up an agreement that has prevented Iran from getting a nuclear weapon, simply because it was negotiated by President Obama. And Trump has threatened to do this without offering any alternative plan to block Iran from getting a nuclear bomb.   There is no doubt that Iran has been a menace in the region. It supports the murderous regime of Assad in Syria, supplies terrorist groups like Hezbollah with weaponry and conducts ballistic missile tests. The United States has and must continue to confront this Iranian aggression. That said, no one was under the illusion that the Iran nuclear agreement would stop Iran from engaging in this conduct. The agreement was premised on the reality that a nuclear-armed Iran would be more of a menace on all these fronts than a non-nuclear Iran. That remains as true today as when the nuclear agreement was signed.    The choice we face right now is between sticking with an agreement that has cut off Iran’s pathways to a bomb or allowing Iran to push forward with a nuclear weapons program. It’s between maintaining U.S. credibility and leadership in the world or empowering our adversaries. It’s between diplomacy or increasing the risk of war. And If Trump kills this deal, it will make it nearly impossible to negotiate a resolution to other critical issues, like the North Korean nuclear crisis. Who will ever enter into an agreement with a country that walks away from its commitments?    I’m urging you to speak out today, contact your friend and families—remind them of what’s at stake. We face enough crises that are not of our own making; we should not pick unnecessary fights that put the security of America and our allies at risk.

About a month ago, when Hurricane Harvey ripped through communities across the Gulf Coast, Wyatt Oroke showed his students at City Springs Middle School a photo of the heartbreaking destruction. His students immediately asked him how they could help.    Mr. Oroke asked his students, “What do you want to do to help?”   Soon after the students at City Springs—a school in Southeast Baltimore that serves some of the city’s poorest families—came together to raise over $1,000 for the people who suffered in Harvey’s path of destruction. The story of their generosity has since gone viral, drawing admirers across the country and even some celebrities—including the Ellen DeGeneres.    As Mr. Oroke previously told The Baltimore Sun, “It’s oftentimes striking how we see those who have the least give the most. I think it’s because they’ve seen that side of things, and have stronger empathy.” You’ve got to watch and read this inspiring story about Mr. Oroke and students from City Springs Middle School.
