I am pleased to report something that seems to be in short supply these days: good news! This past week the Senate passed, and the President signed, the Frederick Douglass Bicentennial Commission Act. This new measure will establish a commission to honor and celebrate the life and work of Frederick Douglass as we mark the 200th anniversary of his birth next year. Most importantly, the Commission determine how the work of Frederick Douglass can guide us on our continuing journey to build a more perfect union.  I was honored to introduce this resolution in the Senate together with my colleague Senator Ben Cardin And thank you to Representatives Eleanor Holmes Norton and Andy Harris for introducing and passing the bill in the House. Thanks also to the Douglass family for helping make this Commission a reality.   Frederick Douglass was an American hero and a great Marylander. Enslaved at birth in Talbot County, he grew to become a national leader in the fight to end slavery and win the right to vote for women. In his twenties, Douglass escaped slavery and eventually fled to England. In 1846 British Quakers raised funds to pay for his freedom and he returned home to the United States. He became one of the greatest orators, writers and social reformers in American history. His autobiography, "Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave," was a bestseller during his lifetime and Douglass played a central role in the abolitionist movement and became a world-renowned leader in the fight to end the evil institution of slavery.   I look forward to working with the Commission to develop a plan for our nation to celebrate and learn from the powerful example of Frederick Douglass.

We need a coherent strategy to address North Korea’s nuclear program, which presents a growing threat to the United States and our allies. Unfortunately, the President's overheated rhetoric has raised the risk of war and reduced the chances for a peaceful solution.  We should take a different approach. A war of words will not denuclearize the Korean Peninsula, but putting real teeth into United Nations sanctions can ratchet up the economic pressure and bring Kim Jung Un to the negotiating table. That's why Senator Toomey and I introduced the bipartisan Otto Warmbier Banking Restrictions Involving North Korea bill, called the BRINK Act.  I am pleased to report that today the Senate Banking Committee voted to pass the bill.  The BRINK Act imposes mandatory sanctions on the foreign banks and companies that facilitate illicit financial transactions for North Korea. It sends an unmistakable message: if you do business with North Korea you will lose access to the U.S. market.  Tonight President Trump will arrive in China. Ninety percent of North Korean trade is with China and Chinese firms have been notorious for violating UN sanctions. I don't know what President Trump will say to President Xi Jingping, but the legislation we passed today is more powerful than any words—it lets China know we are serious about penalizing any Chinese banks that help the North Korean regime.  President Theodore Roosevelt wisely advised us to "speak softly and carry a big stick." Trump should heed this advice by dialing down the rhetoric and using the BRINK Act to increase economic pressure on North Korea to negotiate a peaceful solution. The Chesapeake Bay is a national and natural treasure. It's also an economic lifeline for much of Maryland's economy. The health our economy—the tourism, boating, and seafood industries—depend on a healthy Bay.    In Maryland, we’ve successfully worked closely with our farmers to make sure we have both a vibrant farming industry on the Eastern Shore and a healthy Bay. Back in 1990, when I was in the Maryland General Assembly, we fought Big Oil together—banning drilling in key parts of the watershed. In 2008, I worked with our farmers and the environmental community to launch the Chesapeake Bay Watershed Initiative—a partnership with farmers to implement agricultural practices to reduce the flow of excessive levels of nutrients and sediments into the Bay.    But our work is far from over.   That’s why today I introduced the bipartisan Chesapeake Bay Farm Bill Enhancements Act. This legislation will triple funding for the Regional Conservation Partnership Program (RCPP) in the farm program—from $100 million to $300 million—and target those resources to better protect the most environmentally fragile areas in vital watersheds across the nation. Those improvements will strengthen the efforts of farmers to build things like manure storage and stream buffers that prevent harmful nutrients from being discharged into sensitive watersheds. I’m pleased to report that this bill is supported by a bipartisan group of senators, representatives, and governors from the Bay Watershed, as well as over 70 environmental organizations—including the Chesapeake Bay Foundation and Choose Clean Water. As we begin work on the Farm Bill, I urge my colleagues to support this legislation. This investment will accelerate our efforts to clean up the Bay and help protect the livelihood all who depend on a healthy watershed.

In Maryland, we have nearly 30,000 TPS recipients, many of whom have been living here legally for over two decades. One of Baltimore’s great traditions is Bea Gaddy’s Thanks for Giving Campaign. The initiative was established by the great Dr. Bea Gaddy—known by many in our community as the Mother Teresa of Baltimore.   Dr. Gaddy rose from poverty to become Baltimore's leading advocates for the homeless and poor. In 1970, she joined the East Baltimore Children’s Fund and used her home as a distribution point for food and clothing—eventually using the experience to create a homeless shelter, the Bea Gaddy Family Center. And in 1981, Gaddy used the winnings from her Maryland State Lottery Ticket of $250 to serve 49 of her neighbors a wonderful Thanksgiving dinner. Over the years, those simple meals grew into service events at which hundreds, then thousands, were fed. Last year I had the joy of joining other volunteers in Baltimore—along with Gaddy’s daughter, Cynthia Brooks, who now heads the organization—to provide a helping hand and feed over 50,000 warm meals to those less fortunate, and I look forward to returning again this holiday season.    So today, let’s give thanks for the blessings we enjoy and for the work the Bea Gaddy Family Center and all those who volunteer to give others a helping hand.

Parks was a woman who dedicated her life to changing our Nation so that all Americans would have the opportunity to experience true freedom and justice. It was her courage and steadfast resolve that launched the Montgomery bus boycott and helped spark the civil rights movement. As we honor her legacy, we must recommit ourselves to stamping out injustice wherever it exists. The best way we can pay tribute to this remarkable woman is by speaking out boldly against inequality and oppression and refusing to accept, ignore, or submit to it.
